title: Shades of Purple: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Purple is more than a color. It sits between red and blue, carrying calm depth and quiet power at the same time. For centuries, purple stood apart. It was rare, difficult to create, and closely tied to royalty, luxury, and wealth. Famous shades like Tyrian purple, Han purple, royal purple, and mauve shaped history and … Read more
content:
Purple is more than a color. It sits between red and blue, carrying calm depth and quiet power at the same time. For centuries, purple stood apart. It was rare, difficult to create, and closely tied to royalty, luxury, and wealth. Famous shades like Tyrian purple, Han purple, royal purple, and mauve shaped history and status across cultures.

In this guide, you will explore over 100 shades of purple, from soft lavender to deep eggplant. Each shade comes with hex, RGB, and CMYK codes, along with its meaning and common uses. This helps you choose the right purple for design, branding, art, or home decor without guesswork.

By the end, you will clearly see how each purple shade looks, feels, and functions. Whether you want something bold, calming, or elegant, this collection makes finding the perfect purple simple and practical.

Purple

Purple, #800080, is the classic, balanced web color precisely halfway between red and blue on the color wheel. Historically, it was famously expensive, derived from rare Tyrian dye from sea snails. Thus, it became a global symbol of royalty, power, and ambition for millennia. Consequently, it’s used in branding for premium products, ceremonial regalia, and to convey a sense of luxury and dignity.

  • HEX #800080
  • RGB 128, 0, 128
  • CMYK 0, 100, 0, 50

Rebecca Purple

Rebecca Purple, #663399, is a deep, warm blend of violet and gray with a distinct earthy quality. This color has a unique digital history; it was formally added to the CSS color list in 2014 as a memorial. Therefore, it carries a modern, poignant significance in web development. It is now used in coding contexts and design to represent thoughtfulness and digital heritage.

  • HEX #663399
  • RGB 102, 51, 153
  • CMYK 33, 67, 0, 40

Royal Purple

Royal Purple, #7851A9, is a rich, saturated hue leaning toward blue with a majestic intensity. Its name directly references its historical use in the robes of emperors and kings. This shade embodies sovereignty, grandeur, and ambition. As a result, it is frequently employed in academic regalia, high-end branding, and awards to denote exceptional status and achievement.

  • HEX #7851A9
  • RGB 120, 81, 169
  • CMYK 29, 52, 0, 34

Indigo

Indigo, #4B0082, is a profound and somber color on the spectrum between blue and violet, named for the ancient dye plant. It was once a valuable commodity traded along historic routes. This deep shade represents intuition, integrity, and deep contemplation. Thus, it is commonly used in denim, spiritual imagery, and as a dramatic alternative to black in fashion and design.

  • HEX #4B0082
  • RGB 75, 0, 130
  • CMYK 42, 100, 0, 49

Dark Purple

Dark Purple, #301934, is an extremely deep, shadowy tone that borders on black with a strong violet undertone. This color evokes the mystery of a night sky or the richness of fertile soil. It is associated with sophistication, mystery, and the subconscious. Consequently, it is an elegant choice for luxurious packaging, dramatic evening wear, and creating a moody, intimate atmosphere in interiors.

  • HEX #301934
  • RGB 48, 25, 52
  • CMYK 8, 52, 0, 80

Light Purple

Light Purple, #C8A2C8, is a soft, muted lilac often described as a pale, grayish violet. This gentle shade carries a nostalgic, vintage quality reminiscent of faded flowers. It symbolizes tenderness, nostalgia, and understated elegance. Therefore, Light Purple is popular in romantic designs, spring-themed decor, and feminine branding where a soft, approachable aesthetic is desired.

  • HEX #C8A2C8
  • RGB 200, 162, 200
  • CMYK 0, 19, 0, 22

Lavender

Lavender, #E6E6FA, is a very pale, whitened violet named after the delicate flowers of the lavender plant. This color is intrinsically linked to calm, cleanliness, and gentle femininity. Its soothing properties make it a staple in wellness and self-care branding, baby nurseries, and minimalist designs. This shade of purple is used to promote relaxation and a sense of spacious tranquility.

  • HEX #E6E6FA
  • RGB 230, 230, 250
  • CMYK 8, 8, 0, 2

Lavender Blush

Lavender Blush, #FFF0F5, is an exceptionally pale, pink-tinged white with just a whisper of violet. It resembles the soft flush on skin, hence its evocative name. This color embodies delicate health, innocence, and subtle romance. As a result, it is a classic choice for wedding stationery, lingerie packaging, and as a warm, clean background color in elegant digital and print designs.

  • HEX #FFF0F5
  • RGB 255, 240, 245
  • CMYK 0, 6, 4, 0

Lavender Purple

Lavender Purple, #967BB6, is a medium-saturated, dusty violet that balances softness with noticeable color presence. This shade is more substantial than its paler cousins, offering a mature floral quality. It represents refined grace, nostalgic charm, and spiritual peace. Therefore, it is effectively used in heritage branding, bohemian decor, and cosmetic packaging to convey gentle sophistication.

  • HEX #967BB6
  • RGB 150, 123, 182
  • CMYK 18, 32, 0, 29

Thistle

Thistle, #D8BFD8, is a light, grayish pink-lavender named after the soft hue of the thistle flower’s bloom. This muted, neutral-toned purple has a quiet, natural elegance. It symbolizes protection, resilience, and modest dignity, echoing the hardy nature of the plant. Consequently, Thistle is often chosen for heraldic emblems, rustic wedding palettes, and sophisticated wall colors that are not overpowering.

  • HEX #D8BFD8
  • RGB 216, 191, 216
  • CMYK 0, 12, 0, 15

Plum

Plum, #8E4585, is a deep, dusty purple with strong red undertones, resembling the skin of the ripe fruit it’s named for. This rich shade carries a sense of vintage opulence and autumnal warmth. Historically, plum dyes were accessible and became associated with dependable luxury. Therefore, Plum is used in mature fashion, luxurious bedding, and festive holiday decor to convey a sense of comfort, abundance, and sophisticated depth.

  • HEX #8E4585
  • RGB 142, 69, 133
  • CMYK 0, 51, 6, 44

Medium Purple

Medium Purple, #9370DB, is a bright, cheerful violet with a significant blue influence and high luminosity. This color is a staple in digital design palettes for its clarity and balance. It evokes feelings of creativity, imagination, and playful modernity. Consequently, Medium Purple is frequently selected for children’s media, artistic software interfaces, and vibrant marketing materials that aim to appear friendly and innovative.

  • HEX #9370DB
  • RGB 147, 112, 219
  • CMYK 33, 49, 0, 14

Dark Orchid

Dark Orchid, #9932CC, is a vivid, saturated purple that leans dramatically toward magenta, capturing the exotic beauty of its floral namesake. This intense hue is both electric and lush, representing rare beauty, dramatic passion, and complexity. As a result, Dark Orchid is a powerful choice for energetic branding, nightlife graphics, and artistic accents that demand attention and convey a sense of mystery and allure.

  • HEX #9932CC
  • RGB 153, 50, 204
  • CMYK 25, 75, 0, 20

Orchid

Orchid, #DA70D6, is a light, pinkish purple that directly mimics the delicate petals of tropical orchid flowers. This color is perceived as exotic, feminine, and joyfully elegant. It became particularly popular in design during the Art Nouveau period for its organic inspiration. Thus, Orchid is ideal for beauty product packaging, spring fashion collections, and designs aiming for a tropical or romantic aesthetic.

  • HEX #DA70D6
  • RGB 218, 112, 214
  • CMYK 0, 49, 2, 15

Fuchsia Purple

Fuchsia Purple, #CC397B, is a bold, vibrant hybrid that sits decisively between deep pink and bright purple. Named after the vivid fuchsia flower, this color is unapologetically energetic and confident. It carries a modern, youthful vibration associated with bold self-expression and digital pop culture. Therefore, Fuchsia Purple is often used in contemporary fashion statements, trendy logo design, and media targeting a dynamic, youthful audience.

  • HEX #CC397B
  • RGB 204, 57, 123
  • CMYK 0, 72, 40, 20

Electric Purple

Electric Purple, #BF00FF, is a blindingly bright, pure spectral hue that appears almost neon. This is an ultra-modern, synthetic color associated with artificial light and digital glow. It symbolizes extreme individuality, futuristic technology, and psychedelic energy. Consequently, Electric Purple is a hallmark of rave culture, sci-fi themes, and eye-catching cybersecurity or gaming branding that wants to feel cutting-edge and intense.

  • HEX #BF00FF
  • RGB 191, 0, 255
  • CMYK 25, 100, 0, 0

Vivid Purple

Vivid Purple, #9F00C5, is a deeply saturated, radiant magenta-purple that commands immediate visual attention. Slightly darker than Electric Purple, it retains a powerful luminosity. This shade embodies vibrant creativity, ambition, and theatrical flair. As such, Vivid Purple is effectively deployed in entertainment industry promotions, artistic festival branding, and product packaging that needs to stand out on a crowded shelf or digital feed.

  • HEX #9F00C5
  • RGB 159, 0, 197
  • CMYK 19, 100, 0, 23

Grape

Grape, #6F2DA8, is a juicy, medium-dark purple that perfectly captures the color of concord grapes. This shade feels both natural and indulgent, evoking sweetness and abundance. It is associated with youthfulness, whimsy, and flavorful richness. Therefore, Grape is commonly found in candy and juice packaging, children’s toys, and playful lifestyle branding that aims to be fun, approachable, and mildly nostalgic.

  • HEX #6F2DA8
  • RGB 111, 45, 168
  • CMYK 34, 73, 0, 34

Amethyst

Amethyst, #9966CC, is a medium-light, transparent-seeming violet named after the popular semi-precious quartz. Historically, amethyst was believed to prevent intoxication and promote clarity. This color carries connotations of spiritual wisdom, tranquility, and refined luxury. Consequently, Amethyst is used in wellness and meditation branding, jewelry design, and designs that seek to communicate balance, peace, and a touch of mystical elegance.

  • HEX #9966CC
  • RGB 153, 102, 204
  • CMYK 25, 50, 0, 20

Deep Amethyst

Deep Amethyst, #5B3F8C, is a dark, subdued violet with a stony, majestic quality, resembling a richly colored gemstone in low light. This shade is more serious and introspective than its lighter counterpart. It symbolizes introspection, depth, and sacred knowledge. As a result, Deep Amethyst is chosen for luxurious, moody interiors, mystical or fantasy themes, and academic regalia in certain fields to denote profound expertise and dignity.

  • HEX #5B3F8C
  • RGB 91, 63, 140
  • CMYK 35, 55, 0, 45

Mauve

Mauve, #E0B0FF, is a pale, grayish violet with a distinct pink undertone, famously known as the first mass-produced aniline dye discovered in 1856. This historical accident, created by chemist William Henry Perkin, revolutionized fashion and industry, sparking a “Mauve Decade.” Consequently, Mauve symbolizes innovation, fleeting trends, and the dawn of synthetic chemistry. Today, it is used in vintage-inspired designs, wedding color palettes, and cosmetics to evoke a sense of antique romance and historical significance.

  • HEX #E0B0FF
  • RGB 224, 176, 255
  • CMYK 12, 31, 0, 0

Dark Mauve

Dark Mauve, #915F6D, is a muted, dusty blend of purple, pink, and brown, resembling a faded rose or dried clay. This sophisticated shade sits at the intersection of neutral and chromatic, offering a sense of earthly maturity and weathered elegance. It is associated with subtlety, resilience, and a timeless, understated aesthetic. Therefore, Dark Mauve is a favored choice for heritage branding, rustic interior design accents, and fashion that aims for a nuanced, mature palette.

  • HEX #915F6D
  • RGB 145, 95, 109
  • CMYK 0, 34, 25, 43

Dusty Purple

Dusty Purple, #B399B2, is a desaturated, medium-light purple with a significant infusion of gray, giving it a soft, weathered appearance. This color evokes the feeling of aged velvet, twilight shadows, and faded grandeur. It represents nostalgia, subtlety, and quiet sophistication. Consequently, Dusty Purple is ideal for shabby chic decor, vintage book covers, and background elements in design where a muted, elegant, and non-intrusive tone is required.

  • HEX #B399B2
  • RGB 179, 153, 178
  • CMYK 0, 15, 1, 30

Pastel Purple

Pastel Purple, #F2E5FF, is an extremely light, almost white violet with a creamy, ethereal quality. This shade is created by tinting pure purple with a large amount of white, resulting in a delicate, dreamlike, and serene effect. It embodies innocence, softness, and imaginative daydreams. As a result, Pastel Purple is widely used in baby products, spring festival themes, and wellness spa branding to promote a calming, gentle, and uplifting atmosphere.

  • HEX #F2E5FF
  • RGB 242, 229, 255
  • CMYK 5, 10, 0, 0

Soft Lilac

Soft Lilac, #C6A0DC, is a gentle, luminous purple with a clear, floral character, lighter than standard lilac but more colorful than pastel. This hue captures the fresh, sweet scent and appearance of blooming lilac bushes. It symbolizes first love, youthful nostalgia, and tranquil happiness. Therefore, Soft Lilac is a perennial favorite for romantic stationery, feminine fragrance packaging, and bedroom decor designed to create a peaceful and cheerful retreat.

  • HEX #C6A0DC
  • RGB 198, 160, 220
  • CMYK 10, 27, 0, 14

Lilac

Lilac, #C8A2D4, is the classic, medium-light purple directly named after the fragrant spring flower, sitting as the definitive reference for this floral hue. It is slightly grayer and more subdued than violet, offering a balanced, friendly, and approachable feel. Lilac represents youthful grace, humility, and the ephemeral beauty of spring. Consequently, it is used in Easter celebrations, bridesmaid dresses, and designs that wish to communicate freshness and gentle charm.

  • HEX #C8A2D4
  • RGB 200, 162, 212
  • CMYK 6, 24, 0, 17

Bright Lilac

Bright Lilac, #D891EF, is a vivid, high-energy version of the traditional flower color, with amplified saturation and lightness. This shade is playful, whimsical, and unambiguously cheerful, cutting through visual noise with its floral electric pop. It embodies creative joy, lighthearted fun, and modern femininity. As such, Bright Lilac is effective in children’s entertainment, trendy social media graphics, and lively event branding that targets a young, energetic audience.

  • HEX #D891EF
  • RGB 216, 145, 239
  • CMYK 10, 39, 0, 6

Pale Lilac

Pale Lilac, #E4D1EC, is a bare-there whisper of purple, a tint so light it often reads as a warm gray or white with a subtle lavender cast. This elusive color creates an airy, spacious, and pristine impression, like early morning light through sheer curtains. It signifies serenity, purity, and a clean slate. Therefore, Pale Lilac is a sophisticated choice for minimalist interiors, high-end cosmetic packaging, and website backgrounds where a sense of calm luxury and open space is paramount.

  • HEX #E4D1EC
  • RGB 228, 209, 236
  • CMYK 3, 11, 0, 7

Heather Purple

Heather Purple, #9E7BB5, is a muted, grayish violet inspired by the natural hue of heather flowers covering moorlands. This color has a natural, rustic, and woolen quality, often associated with traditional tweeds and landscapes. It represents solitude, hardiness, and understated beauty. Consequently, Heather Purple is used in heritage crafts branding, outdoor apparel, and rustic wedding themes to evoke a sense of connection to nature and timeless, weathered elegance.

  • HEX #9E7BB5
  • RGB 158, 123, 181
  • CMYK 13, 32, 0, 29

Wisteria

Wisteria, #C9A0DC, is a light, luminous purple with a distinct blue undertone, mirroring the cascading blooms of the wisteria vine. This shade is dreamy, enchanting, and slightly cooler than true lilac, suggesting a fairy-tale ambiance. It symbolizes welcoming beauty, long life, and creative inspiration drawn from nature. As a result, Wisteria is popular in garden-themed designs, fantasy book covers, and spring fashion to capture a sense of magical, abundant growth.

  • HEX #C9A0DC
  • RGB 201, 160, 220
  • CMYK 9, 27, 0, 14

Deep Purple

Deep Purple, #36013F, is an intensely dark, blackened violet that is almost indistinguishable from black in low light, revealing its rich purple heart only in brightness. This shade evokes the profound mystery of outer space and the velvet darkness of night. It represents the subconscious, luxury, and solemn power. Consequently, Deep Purple is used in high-end audio equipment branding (reminiscent of the rock band), ultra-luxurious product packaging, and theatrical set designs to create an atmosphere of intense depth and sophisticated drama.

  • HEX #36013F
  • RGB 54, 1, 63
  • CMYK 14, 98, 0, 75

Byzantium

Byzantium, #702963, is a dark, reddish purple with a muted, regal saturation, named after the magnificent Tyrian purple dyes of the ancient Byzantine Empire. This color historically signified imperial authority, immense wealth, and religious significance. It carries a weight of history, solemnity, and opulent gravity. Therefore, Byzantium is employed in historical documentaries, academic insignia, and designs that need to convey a sense of ancient, enduring prestige and sophisticated richness.

  • HEX #702963
  • RGB 112, 41, 99
  • CMYK 0, 63, 12, 56

Tyrian Purple

Tyrian Purple, #66023C, is a deep, blood-reddened purple, famous as the specific, astronomically expensive dye extracted from Murex sea snails for royal garments in antiquity. To produce an ounce required thousands of mollusks, making it worth more than its weight in gold. This color is the original symbol of supreme status, exclusivity, and power. As such, Tyrian Purple is referenced in historical art, luxury branding narratives, and heraldry to denote the pinnacle of rare and unattainable luxury.

  • HEX #66023C
  • RGB 102, 2, 60
  • CMYK 0, 98, 41, 60

Imperial Purple

Imperial Purple, #602F6B, is a somber, dignified purple with balanced red and blue tones, slightly more accessible than Tyrian Purple but still deeply authoritative. This shade was adopted by later empires as a more feasible symbol of royalty. It embodies majestic rule, tradition, and judicial dignity. Consequently, Imperial Purple is found in university robes, ceremonial banners, and the branding of premium institutions that wish to project an image of established, respected authority and legacy.

  • HEX #602F6B
  • RGB 96, 47, 107
  • CMYK 10, 56, 0, 58

Eggplant

Eggplant, #614051, is a very dark, muted purple-brown that accurately matches the skin of the aubergine vegetable. This earthy, organic shade is sophisticated, grounded, and unexpectedly versatile. It represents culinary richness, autumnal harvest, and understated luxury. Therefore, Eggplant is a popular choice in interior design for feature walls, gourmet food branding, and fall fashion collections, offering a deep, warm neutral that is far more interesting than basic black or brown.

  • HEX #614051
  • RGB 97, 64, 81
  • CMYK 0, 34, 16, 62

Dark Eggplant

Dark Eggplant, #3F2A3C, is an even deeper, shadowy version of its namesake, bordering on black with subtle hints of purple and burgundy. This color is ultra-dramatic, cozy, and enveloping, reminiscent of a night garden. It evokes a sense of mysterious depth, intimate secrecy, and plush comfort. As a result, Dark Eggplant is used in luxurious bedroom decor, high-end restaurant interiors, and dramatic photography backdrops to create a sense of intimate, sophisticated seclusion.

  • HEX #3F2A3C
  • RGB 63, 42, 60
  • CMYK 0, 33, 5, 75

Mulberry

Mulberry, #70193D, is a deep, red-dominated purple that mirrors the jam-like richness of the mulberry fruit. This shade is luscious, bold, and slightly tart in its visual impact. It symbolizes sacrifice, wisdom, and passionate intensity, linked to ancient legends of love and tragedy. Consequently, Mulberry is effective in bold fashion statements, decadent dessert packaging, and branding that wants to feel passionate, flavorful, and richly confident without being overly sweet.

  • HEX #70193D
  • RGB 112, 25, 61
  • CMYK 0, 78, 46, 56

Raisin Purple

Raisin Purple, #2D1B2E, is a dark, desaturated purple with strong brown and black tones, resembling a dried grape. This color is earthy, complex, and aged, evoking leather-bound books and vintage wine. It represents antiquity, wisdom, and rustic maturity. Therefore, Raisin Purple is ideal for heritage brands, luxury leather goods packaging, and scholarly publications where a sense of timelessness, depth, and classic refinement is essential.

  • HEX #2D1B2E
  • RGB 45, 27, 46
  • CMYK 2, 41, 0, 82

Wine Purple

Wine Purple, #4A001F, is a very deep, blackened red-purple that captures the color of a full-bodied red wine like Shiraz or Cabernet in a dimly lit room. This shade is sophisticated, robust, and sensual, associated with celebration, maturity, and refined taste. As such, Wine Purple is a natural choice for vineyard and winery branding, formal event invitations, and luxury cosmetic lines that aim to communicate depth, indulgence, and classic elegance.

  • HEX #4A001F
  • RGB 74, 0, 31
  • CMYK 0, 100, 58, 71

Velvet Purple

Velvet Purple, #3F1E4D, is a dense, plush purple with a blue undertone, named for the deep, light-absorbing richness of velvet fabric. This color is inherently luxurious, tactile, and dramatic, suggesting texture even in flat design. It embodies opulence, night-time glamour, and ceremonial grandeur. Consequently, Velvet Purple is used in theatre curtains, formal evening wear, high-end gift box lining, and designs that seek to evoke a tangible sense of lavish, traditional luxury.

  • HEX #3F1E4D
  • RGB 63, 30, 77
  • CMYK 18, 61, 0, 70

Ultra Violet

Ultra Violet, #645394, is a muted, grayish blue-purple that Pantone selected as the 2018 Color of the Year, describing it as a “dramatically provocative and thoughtful” shade. This complex color suggests mystery, cosmic exploration, and artistic experimentation. It represents inventiveness, counterculture, and visionary thinking. Consequently, Ultra Violet is used in progressive technology branding, avant-garde fashion, and spiritual wellness design to signal creativity that looks toward the future.

  • HEX #645394
  • RGB 100, 83, 148
  • CMYK 32, 44, 0, 42

Blue Violet

Blue Violet, #8A2BE2, is a vivid, electric blue-leaning purple that is one of the original web colors. This shade is dynamic, bright, and digitally friendly, sitting clearly between indigo and violet on the spectrum. It symbolizes electric energy, vibrant individuality, and a playful spirit. Therefore, Blue Violet is a staple in creative software UIs, gaming graphics, and youth-oriented marketing where a bold, energetic, and slightly futuristic feel is desired.

  • HEX #8A2BE2
  • RGB 138, 43, 226
  • CMYK 39, 81, 0, 11

Dark Violet

Dark Violet, #9400D3, is a deep, intensely saturated purple that is slightly darker and redder than standard violet, famously part of the “Roy G. Biv” mnemonic for the colors of the rainbow. This color is rich, luminous, and slightly mystical. It evokes a sense of magical transformation, ambition, and dignified creativity. As a result, Dark Violet is often chosen for magic-themed media, artistic studio branding, and designs that need a purple with substantial weight and chromatic punch.

  • HEX #9400D3
  • RGB 148, 0, 211
  • CMYK 30, 100, 0, 17

Violet

Violet, #7F00FF, is the pure spectral hue at the short-wavelength end of the visible light spectrum, often confused with purple but is a true spectral color. This shade is vibrant, luminous, and associated with light itself. It represents imagination, inspiration, and high spiritual vibration. Consequently, Violet is used in meditation imagery, psychedelic art, and branding for creative or holistic industries to convey a sense of pure, uplifting energy and transcendent ideas.

  • HEX #7F00FF
  • RGB 127, 0, 255
  • CMYK 50, 100, 0, 0

Light Violet

Light Violet, #B18FCF, is a soft, medium-toned purple with a significant gray influence, making it gentle and easy to pair. This muted shade is calming, romantic, and subtly nostalgic. It embodies gentle creativity, sentimental memory, and serene grace. Therefore, Light Violet is a versatile choice for bedroom decor, floral arrangements, and background textures in design where a soothing yet distinctly purple presence is needed without overwhelming intensity.

  • HEX #B18FCF
  • RGB 177, 143, 207
  • CMYK 14, 31, 0, 19

African Violet

African Violet, #B284BE, is a grayish, medium-light purple with a warm pink undertone, named after the popular houseplant known for its fuzzy leaves and cheerful blooms. This friendly, approachable color symbolizes devotion, faithfulness, and understated joy. It carries a domestic, comforting, and nurturing connotation. As such, African Violet is effectively used in craft supplies, cozy home goods branding, and healthcare environments to promote feelings of care, warmth, and tranquil happiness.

  • HEX #B284BE
  • RGB 178, 132, 190
  • CMYK 6, 31, 0, 25

Pansy Purple

Pansy Purple, #78184A, is a deep, reddish purple that draws its name from the velvety, dark face of the pansy flower, which often bears striking dark markings. This color is dramatic, romantic, and slightly melancholic, echoing the flower’s symbolic association with loving thoughts and remembrance. It represents quiet passion, cherished memories, and thoughtful elegance. Consequently, Pansy Purple is chosen for memorial tributes, sophisticated fragrance packaging, and autumn floral designs.

  • HEX #78184A
  • RGB 120, 24, 74
  • CMYK 0, 80, 38, 53

Purple Heart

Purple Heart, #69359C, is a strong, blue-based purple named after the prestigious United States military decoration awarded for bravery. This gives the color an immediate association with courage, honor, and sacrifice. It is a shade of respect, nobility, and unwavering principle. Therefore, Purple Heart is used not only in military contexts but also in awards programs, leadership branding, and designs that aim to communicate dignity, valor, and esteemed achievement.

  • HEX #69359C
  • RGB 105, 53, 156
  • CMYK 33, 66, 0, 39

Iris Purple

Iris Purple, #5A4FCF, is a bright, clear purple with a dominant blue tone, inspired by the stunning iris flower. This luminous shade sits closer to periwinkle and is eye-catching, majestic, and serene. It symbolizes faith, wisdom, and hopeful messages, tied to the Greek goddess Iris who was a messenger of the gods. As a result, Iris Purple is popular in spiritual and wellness branding, artistic portfolios, and designs that wish to appear both trustworthy and creatively inspired.

  • HEX #5A4FCF
  • RGB 90, 79, 207
  • CMYK 57, 62, 0, 19

Cosmic Purple

Cosmic Purple, #2E1A47, is an extremely dark, blue-shifted purple that evokes the vast, mysterious depths of interstellar space dotted with distant nebulae. This color is infinite, mysterious, and profound. It represents the unknown, cosmic wonder, and deep introspection. Consequently, Cosmic Purple is a perfect choice for astronomy-related media, sci-fi video games, and avant-garde fashion that seeks to create a sense of awe, limitless possibility, and otherworldly depth.

  • HEX #2E1A47
  • RGB 46, 26, 71
  • CMYK 35, 63, 0, 72

Mystic Purple

Mystic Purple, #D65282, is a vibrant, pink-dominated purple that leans more toward magenta, creating a sense of magical allure and passionate mystery. This color blends the spirituality of purple with the energy of pink, symbolizing enchantment, emotional depth, and transformative love. It evokes a sense of otherworldly charm and mystical romance. Consequently, Mystic Purple is often used in fantasy literature covers, tarot and astrology branding, and specialty cosmetics to suggest a connection to the unseen and the emotionally profound.

  • HEX #D65282
  • RGB 214, 82, 130

Retro Purple, #9A4D8C, is a bold, slightly muted magenta-purple that specifically references the vibrant, synthetic color palette of the 1960s and 70s. This color is funky, energetic, and nostalgically futuristic. It embodies pop culture, playful rebellion, and a groovy aesthetic. Consequently, Retro Purple is essential for vinyl record sleeves, retro-themed diners, and fashion lines aiming to capture the optimistic, bold, and slightly kitschy vibe of mid-century modern design.

  • HEX #9A4D8C
  • RGB 154, 77, 140
  • CMYK 0, 50, 9, 40

Classic Purple

Classic Purple, #663366, is a medium-dark, balanced purple also known as “Imperial” or deep lilac, recognized for its timeless and traditional appeal. This shade is neither too red nor too blue, representing the enduring, universal essence of purple. It symbolizes heritage, dignity, and spiritual depth. As such, Classic Purple is a reliable choice for corporate logos seeking a conservative yet distinctive color, academic robes, and traditional ceremonial accessories.

  • HEX #663366
  • RGB 102, 51, 102
  • CMYK 0, 50, 0, 60

Old Lilac

Old Lilac, #B09DB9, is a pale, grayish lavender that looks like the color of lilac flowers after they have dried and faded, losing their vibrant bloom. This color is gentle, melancholic, and deeply nostalgic. It embodies faded beauty, quiet reminiscence, and gentle aging. Therefore, Old Lilac is perfect for historical romance novel covers, antique linen branding, and background colors in designs that require a soft, poetic, and sentimentally rich atmosphere.

  • HEX #B09DB9
  • RGB 176, 157, 185
  • CMYK 5, 15, 0, 27

Antique Purple

Antique Purple, #7F5A83, is a muted, dusty violet with a brown undertone, reminiscent of tarnished silver set with amethysts or faded velvet in a historic portrait. This shade is time-honored, valuable, and carries a patina of age. It represents enduring value, collected history, and refined decay. Consequently, Antique Purple is used in antique shop branding, museum exhibit design, and high-end reproduction furniture finishes to evoke a sense of curated history and proven worth.

  • HEX #7F5A83
  • RGB 127, 90, 131
  • CMYK 3, 31, 0, 49

Heritage Purple

Heritage Purple, #6B4E71, is a dark, subdued purple-gray that suggests family crests, aged parchment with faded ink, and the stones of ancient buildings. This color is rooted, solemn, and speaks to lineage. It symbolizes tradition, legacy, and the weight of history. As a result, Heritage Purple is employed by institutions like banks, universities, and law firms in their branding to project stability, deep-rooted trust, and a solemn commitment to enduring principles.

  • HEX #6B4E71
  • RGB 107, 78, 113
  • CMYK 5, 31, 0, 56

Victorian Purple

Victorian Purple, #5F4A66, is a dark, somber, and complex purple heavily mixed with black and brown, reflecting the formal, heavy, and ornate aesthetic of the Victorian era. This shade is serious, opulent, and slightly restrictive. It embodies mourning, strict social codes, and elaborate, dark luxury. Therefore, Victorian Purple is used in period drama costuming, gothic literature covers, and designs that aim to recreate the dense, moralistic, yet lavish atmosphere of the 19th century.

  • HEX #5F4A66
  • RGB 95, 74, 102
  • CMYK 7, 27, 0, 60

Archive Purple

Archive Purple, #8A738E, is a cool, dusty lavender-gray that mimics the color of old file boxes, aged book bindings, and microfiche readers in a library’s special collections. This color is organized, preserved, and quietly knowledgeable. It represents cataloged memory, institutional knowledge, and orderly history. Consequently, Archive Purple is an apt choice for library interfaces, data storage company branding, and academic journal design to communicate secure preservation and intellectual curation.

  • HEX #8A738E
  • RGB 138, 115, 142
  • CMYK 3, 19, 0, 44

Muted Lilac

Muted Lilac, #C3B1CC, is a very pale, grayish lilac that has been significantly softened, resulting in a calm, neutral, and sophisticated pastel. This shade is soothing, airy, and effortlessly elegant, avoiding the sweetness of brighter lilacs. It embodies subtle romance, modern tranquility, and refined gentleness. As such, Muted Lilac is a popular wall color in modern interiors, a base for minimalist wedding themes, and in packaging for premium skincare to suggest purity and quiet luxury.

  • HEX #C3B1CC
  • RGB 195, 177, 204
  • CMYK 4, 13, 0, 20

Soft Grape

Soft Grape, #B784C5, is a light, luminous purple with a clear pink undertone, resembling the delicate skin of a green grape tinged with violet. This color is sweet, juicy, and refreshingly light. It symbolizes gentle indulgence, fresh flavor, and playful sophistication. Therefore, Soft Grape is charmingly used in yogurt or dessert packaging, children’s clothing, and spring garden party decor to impart a sense of playful, delicious, and softly vibrant energy.

  • HEX #B784C5
  • RGB 183, 132, 197
  • CMYK 7, 33, 0, 23

title: Shades of Orange: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Orange is more than just a color. It radiates warmth, energy, and creativity. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of orange. From bright tangerine to deep pumpkin, each shade carries its own character. We include hex, RGB, and CMYK codes for every color. You will also learn the meaning and common uses … Read more
content:
Orange is more than just a color. It radiates warmth, energy, and creativity. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of orange. From bright tangerine to deep pumpkin, each shade carries its own character.

We include hex, RGB, and CMYK codes for every color. You will also learn the meaning and common uses of each shade. This makes it simple to choose the right orange for design, art, or decoration.

By the end of this guide, you will understand how each orange looks, feels, and works. You can quickly find the perfect shade for your project.

Let’s jump into the vibrant world of orange shades.

Amber

Amber is a vivid, warm shade of yellow-orange that takes its name from the fossilized tree resin known for its captivating translucence and ancient inclusions. Historically, this organic gemstone was a prized commodity along the European trade routes and was often crafted into jewelry and amulets believed to hold protective or healing properties. The color itself embodies warmth, energy, and a timeless glow, reminiscent of both sunlight and the preserved essence of prehistoric forests. Consequently, it is effectively utilized in traffic warning signals, high-visibility safety gear, and autumnal decor, where its inherent luminosity commands attention and evokes a sense of enduring energy.

  • HEX #FFBF00
  • RGB 255, 191, 0
  • CMYK 0, 25, 100, 0

Tangerine

Tangerine is a bold, highly saturated reddish-orange, directly and vividly named after the popular citrus fruit. This color designation emerged in the English language in the late 19th century, perfectly capturing the fruit’s zesty, vibrant, and tangy peel. It is a shade that radiates enthusiasm, creativity, and fun, often associated with youthful energy and tropical vibrancy. As a result, Tangerine is a dominant and popular choice for athletic wear, energetic beverage branding, and lively summer fashion collections, where its bright and inviting nature stimulates excitement and stands out powerfully.

  • HEX #F08000
  • RGB 240, 128, 0
  • CMYK 0, 47, 100, 6

Coral

Coral is a sophisticated and lively blend of pink, orange, and a touch of red, directly inspired by the natural hues of marine coral skeletons. This color gained significant popularity in interior design and fashion during the 18th century, symbolizing delicate beauty and oceanic elegance. It carries connotations of warmth, vivacity, and a gentle femininity, often evoking imagery of tropical reefs and sunsets. Therefore, Coral is extensively used in cosmetics, resort wear, and home decor accents, providing a refreshing and subtly energizing alternative to standard orange or pink tones.

  • HEX #FF7F50
  • RGB 255, 127, 80
  • CMYK 0, 50, 69, 0

Pumpkin Orange

Pumpkin Orange is a rich, deeply saturated orange that serves as the quintessential hue of its namesake autumn gourd. This color is intrinsically linked to harvest festivals, particularly Halloween and Thanksgiving, symbolizing abundance, festivity, and the changing seasons. It embodies a sense of wholesome warmth, rustic comfort, and approachable vibrancy. As such, Pumpkin Orange is a staple in holiday-themed marketing, autumn home decor, and culinary branding, where it immediately conjures feelings of tradition, coziness, and seasonal joy.

  • HEX #FF7518
  • RGB 255, 117, 24
  • CMYK 0, 54, 91, 0

Mahogany

Mahogany is a deep, reddish-brown color that takes its name from the highly prized tropical hardwood renowned for its durability, fine grain, and rich coloration. Historically associated with luxury, the wood has been used for centuries in high-quality furniture, shipbuilding, and musical instruments, representing craftsmanship, stability, and enduring value. This color evokes a sense of sophisticated tradition, grounded strength, and timeless elegance. Consequently, Mahogany is frequently employed in luxury branding, traditional interior design schemes, and leather goods, where it communicates richness and reliable quality.

  • HEX #C04000
  • RGB 192, 64, 0
  • CMYK 0, 67, 100, 25

Apricot

Apricot is a soft, pale orange with strong pinkish undertones, named after the flesh of the delicate stone fruit. This pastel shade rose to prominence in fashion and design for its subtle, flattering, and calming qualities, often associated with romanticism and softness. It carries meanings of modesty, gentleness, and springtime renewal, offering a more muted and sophisticated alternative to brighter oranges. Thus, Apricot is commonly found in bridesmaid dresses, spring cosmetic palettes, and nursery decor, where it provides a warm yet serene and uplifting atmosphere.

  • HEX #FBCEB1
  • RGB 251, 206, 177
  • CMYK 0, 18, 29, 2

Burnt Orange

Burnt Orange is a dark, earthy shade of orange with strong brown undertones, evoking the appearance of orange pigment that has been literally charred or oxidized. Popularized in the 1960s and 70s, this color became emblematic of autumnal warmth, rustic earthiness, and a relaxed, bohemian spirit. It suggests comfort, resilience, and a connection to nature, feeling both vibrant and subdued. Accordingly, Burnt Orange is a hallmark of university sports teams, fall fashion, and cozy interior design, where it delivers a punch of color without being overly bright or neon.

  • HEX #CC5500
  • RGB 204, 85, 0
  • CMYK 0, 58, 100, 20

Neon Orange

Neon Orange is an intensely bright, fluorescent orange that appears to emit its own glowing light, mimicking the effect of neon gas illumination. Developed through modern synthetic pigments, this color is the epitome of high-energy, extreme visibility, and futuristic boldness. It screams attention, urgency, and dynamic action, making it impossible to ignore. Therefore, Neon Orange is strategically used for high-visibility safety equipment, extreme sports apparel, and nightclub or festival graphics, where its radiant properties ensure maximum impact both day and night.

  • HEX #FF5F1F
  • RGB 255, 95, 31
  • CMYK 0, 63, 88, 0

Butterscotch

Butterscotch is a warm, medium orange-brown hue inspired by the creamy, sugary confection made from butter and brown sugar. This color evokes immediate sensory associations with sweetness, indulgence, and nostalgic comfort food. It embodies a sense of creamy richness, homely warmth, and approachable luxury. As a result, Butterscotch is effectively utilized in bakery branding, cozy knitwear, and warm-toned interior design elements, where it creates an inviting, comforting, and subtly decadent ambiance.

  • HEX #E3963E
  • RGB 227, 150, 62
  • CMYK 0, 34, 73, 11

Cinnamon

Cinnamon is a warm, spicy reddish-brown color, named after the aromatic bark of the cinnamon tree used as a treasured spice for millennia. Historically, this spice was so valuable it was considered a gift fit for monarchs and deities, symbolizing wealth, warmth, and exotic luxury. The color carries connotations of spicy warmth, rustic comfort, and aromatic richness. Consequently, Cinnamon is a popular choice for cosy autumn fashion, warm-neutral home interiors, and gourmet food packaging, where it imparts a sense of earthy sophistication and sensory appeal.

  • HEX #D27D2D
  • RGB 210, 125, 45
  • CMYK 0, 40, 79, 18

Light Orange

Light Orange is a soft, pale tint of orange created by adding significant white to a base orange hue, resulting in a gentle and airy appearance. This shade retains the cheerful essence of orange but in a much more subdued, delicate, and approachable form, often associated with softness and innocence. It evokes feelings of gentle warmth, optimism, and a soothing energy, making it far less aggressive than its saturated counterparts. Therefore, Light Orange is frequently chosen for nursery designs, spring-themed graphics, and soft drink packaging, where it aims to convey a friendly and calming vibrancy.

  • HEX #FFD580
  • RGB 255, 213, 128
  • CMYK 0, 16, 50, 0

Goldenrod

Goldenrod is a deep, golden-yellow shade with strong orange undertones, named after the vibrant wildflower that blooms in late summer and autumn. Historically, the plant itself was used to produce a dye, and the color became associated with the rich, warm light of autumn afternoons. This hue symbolizes vitality, encouragement, and a mature, harvested wealth. Consequently, Goldenrod is often used in traditional decor, floral designs, and as an accent color in vintage graphics, where it provides a classic, warm, and somewhat rustic golden touch.

  • HEX #DAA520
  • RGB 218, 165, 32
  • CMYK 0, 24, 85, 15

Salmon

Salmon is a light pinkish-orange color, precisely mimicking the hue of the flesh of the salmon fish. This delicate shade strikes a balance between the energy of orange and the tenderness of pink, creating a flattering, soothing, and organic impression. It carries connotations of health, freshness, and understated vibrancy, often linked to wellness and natural beauty. Accordingly, Salmon is a staple in cosmetics (especially blushes and lipsticks), spa branding, and casual apparel, where it offers a warm, healthy glow that is universally appealing.

  • HEX #FA8072
  • RGB 250, 128, 114
  • CMYK 0, 49, 54, 2

Safety Orange

Safety Orange is a high-visibility, intensely saturated orange specifically formulated and standardized for maximum visual detection in hazardous environments. Also known as blaze orange, its development was driven by the need for unmissable contrast against most natural backgrounds. This color is legally mandated for certain safety equipment, hunter’s clothing, and traffic cones, as it signals immediate caution, danger, and mandatory attention. Thus, its primary use is purely functional, designed to save lives by being the most conspicuous color in a wide range of lighting conditions.

  • HEX #FF5F15
  • RGB 255, 95, 21
  • CMYK 0, 63, 92, 0

Pastel Orange

Pastel Orange is a very pale, soft, and muted tone of orange achieved by mixing pure orange with a large amount of white and sometimes a hint of gray. This shade belongs to the pastel family, known for its soft, dreamy, and calming aesthetic that became particularly popular in retro and springtime designs. It evokes feelings of sweetness, nostalgia, and gentle cheerfulness without any overwhelming intensity. As a result, Pastel Orange is commonly used in Easter decorations, vintage-themed branding, and baby clothing, where it provides a warm yet exceptionally soft and friendly pop of color.

  • HEX #FAC898
  • RGB 250, 200, 152
  • CMYK 0, 20, 39, 2

Red Orange

Red Orange is a vibrant, fiery hue that sits exactly on the border between red and orange, embodying the passionate heat of both parent colors. This electric shade is associated with intense energy, volcanic heat, and urgent dynamism. It symbolizes confidence, determination, and a bold, adventurous spirit, often used to represent physical endurance and extreme sports. Consequently, Red Orange is a powerful choice for sports car detailing, action-oriented branding, and warning graphics, where it communicates high energy and demands an immediate, energetic response.

  • HEX #FF4433
  • RGB 255, 68, 51
  • CMYK 0, 73, 80, 0

Desert

Desert is a pale, sandy tone of light orange-brown that directly reflects the vast, sun-bleached landscapes of arid regions. This color evokes the parched earth, rolling sand dunes, and the serene, expansive heat of desert environments. It carries meanings of warmth, barren beauty, resilience, and isolation, offering a neutral yet warm foundation. Therefore, Desert is effectively utilized in camouflage patterns, southwestern-style interior design, and eco-friendly product packaging, where it conveys a natural, earthy, and sun-warmed aesthetic.

  • HEX #FAD5A5
  • RGB 250, 213, 165
  • CMYK 0, 15, 34, 2

Copper

Copper is a reddish-brown metallic color named after the malleable elemental metal known for its high thermal and electrical conductivity. Historically significant in the dawn of human civilization during the Copper Age, this color is associated with innovation, craftsmanship, and monetary value (as in pennies). It suggests a warm, polished glow, vintage appeal, and rustic durability. Accordingly, Copper is popular in metallic finishes for decor and jewelry, automotive detailing, and branding for artisanal or tech products, where it implies both traditional quality and modern conductivity.

  • HEX #B87333
  • RGB 184, 115, 51
  • CMYK 0, 38, 72, 28

Bronze

Bronze is a medium to dark brownish-orange with a subdued metallic sheen, named after the alloy of copper and tin that defined a pivotal era in human technological progress. This ancient metal was used for tools, weapons, and sculptures, symbolizing strength, endurance, and artistic achievement. The color Bronze represents third-place honor, timeless tradition, and a weathered, sturdy elegance. Consequently, it is used for award statues, antique restoration, and autumn/winter fashion, where it conveys a sense of dignified, aged, and prestigious warmth.

  • HEX #CD7F32
  • RGB 205, 127, 50
  • CMYK 0, 38, 76, 20

Peach

Peach is a light, pinkish-yellow orange that closely resembles the soft, blushing skin of the ripe fruit. This color is universally regarded as flattering, soothing, and inherently sweet, often associated with innocence and modesty in Western culture. It evokes feelings of warmth, approachability, and gentle joy, offering a friendly and non-threatening vibrancy. As such, Peach is extensively used in cosmetics for fair skin tones, wedding party attire, and healthcare or hospitality design, where it aims to create a comforting, welcoming, and softly optimistic environment.

  • HEX #FFE5B4
  • RGB 255, 229, 180
  • CMYK 0, 10, 29, 0

Coral Pink

Coral Pink is a soft, warm pink with distinct orange undertones, sitting between the vibrancy of coral and the sweetness of pink. This shade retains the lively character of its parent color but in a more delicate, romantic, and less aggressive form. It evokes feelings of playful charm, affectionate warmth, and tropical femininity. Consequently, Coral Pink is a popular choice for women’s fashion, cosmetic packaging, and children’s toys, where it provides a cheerful and friendly hue that is energetic yet gentle.

  • HEX #F88379
  • RGB 248, 131, 121
  • CMYK 0, 47, 51, 3

Sunset Orange

Sunset Orange is a rich, radiant orange with strong red and pink influences, capturing the intense and fleeting colors of the sky at dusk. This dramatic hue embodies the grand finale of the day, symbolizing passion, transition, and breathtaking beauty. It carries connotations of drama, warmth, and inspirational awe, often used to evoke a sense of wonder. Therefore, Sunset Orange is effectively utilized in travel and tourism marketing, artistic backgrounds, and evening wear, where it communicates a powerful, emotionally resonant warmth.

  • HEX #FA5F55
  • RGB 250, 95, 85
  • CMYK 0, 62, 66, 2

Sienna

Sienna is an earthy, reddish-brown natural pigment originally derived from clay rich in iron oxide and manganese. Historically used in art since the Renaissance, its name comes from the Italian city of Siena, where it was extensively mined. This color represents rustic earthiness, natural warmth, and classical artistry. As a result, Sienna is a fundamental color in an artist’s palette and is widely used in traditional interior design, leatherwork, and landscape painting, providing a stable, warm, and natural base tone.

  • HEX #A0522D
  • RGB 160, 82, 45
  • CMYK 0, 49, 72, 37

Ochre

Ochre is a family of natural clay pigments ranging from yellow to deep orange or brown; the specific orange hue is a deep, golden orange-brown. One of the oldest pigments used by humans, found in ancient cave paintings worldwide, it signifies primal connection, earth, and enduring tradition. This color embodies warmth, antiquity, and the raw materials of the earth itself. Consequently, Ochre is used in historical art restoration, ethnographic designs, and earthy fashion, linking modern use to a deeply ancient human practice.

  • HEX #CC7722
  • RGB 204, 119, 34
  • CMYK 0, 42, 83, 20

Yellow Orange

Yellow Orange, also known as marigold, is a bright, cheerful hue that leans more toward yellow than red on the color spectrum. This is the color of high-visibility happiness, citrus fruits, and vibrant sunshine. It symbolizes optimism, enthusiasm, and youthful energy, acting as a more approachable and less intense sibling to pure orange. Thus, Yellow Orange is frequently found in children’s products, summer advertising, and sports accessories, where it projects a fun, accessible, and energetic vibe.

  • HEX #FFAA33
  • RGB 255, 170, 51
  • CMYK 0, 33, 80, 0

Burnt Sienna

Burnt Sienna is a warm, reddish-brown pigment made by roasting raw sienna, which deepens its color from a yellowish hue to a rich, earthy orange-brown. Valued by artists for its transparency and warmth, it is a staple for painting terracotta, autumn leaves, and skin tones in shadow. This color evokes a sense of refined earthiness, aged warmth, and artistic depth. Accordingly, it is essential in fine art, particularly watercolor and oil painting, and in upscale rustic decor, where it adds a complex, natural warmth.

  • HEX #E97451
  • RGB 233, 116, 81
  • CMYK 0, 50, 65, 9

Cadmium Orange

Cadmium Orange is a dense, opaque, and brilliantly saturated orange made from cadmium sulfide pigments developed in the 19th century. Celebrated for its exceptional purity, permanence, and intense covering power, it became a revolutionary color for artists seeking vibrant, non-fading oranges. This hue represents bold artistic statement, chemical brilliance, and unadulterated vibrancy. Consequently, it is a critical tube color for modern fine artists, industrial plastics, and safety applications, prized for its powerful and lasting impact.

  • HEX #F28C28
  • RGB 242, 140, 40
  • CMYK 0, 42, 83, 5

Mango

Mango is a luscious, tropical orange with a noticeable golden-yellow undertone, directly inspired by the flesh of the ripe mango fruit. This juicy color evokes immediate associations with sweetness, exotic flavor, and vibrant tropical locales. It symbolizes hospitality, summer abundance, and sensory delight. Therefore, Mango is widely used in food and beverage branding, resort wear, and summertime promotional materials, where it effectively communicates a message of delicious, sun-soaked enjoyment.

  • HEX #F4BB44
  • RGB 244, 187, 68
  • CMYK 0, 23, 72, 4

Pink Orange

Pink Orange is a soft, luminous blend where pink and orange are balanced to create a uniquely warm and flattering pastel. This shade sits in the coral family but is distinctly lighter and more ethereal, reminiscent of a glowing sunset or certain tropical flowers. It carries meanings of tenderness, playful romance, and a soft vibrancy. As a result, Pink Orange is often chosen for contemporary fashion, modern website accents, and beauty product design, offering a fresh and modern take on warm tones.

  • HEX #F89880
  • RGB 248, 152, 128
  • CMYK 0, 39, 48, 3

Terra Cotta

Terra Cotta is a warm, reddish-brown color named after the fired clay used for centuries to make pottery, roofing tiles, and architectural details. Literally meaning “baked earth” in Italian, this color is the essence of Mediterranean warmth, rustic craftsmanship, and organic material. It evokes a sense of handmade authenticity, earthy stability, and sun-drenched tradition. Consequently, Terra Cotta is ubiquitous in Mediterranean and Southwestern architecture, garden pots, and artisanal home decor, where it provides a naturally warm and textural element.

  • HEX #E3735E
  • RGB 227, 115, 94
  • CMYK 0, 49, 59, 11

Butternut

Butternut is a warm, pale shade of orange-brown, reminiscent of the flesh of the butternut squash. This color embodies the essence of autumn harvest, wholesome nutrition, and rustic comfort food. It evokes feelings of organic warmth, simplicity, and earthy sweetness, offering a muted and approachable alternative to brighter oranges. Therefore, Butternut is effectively used in farmers’ market branding, cozy knitwear, and kitchenware design, where it creates an inviting and naturalistic ambiance.

  • HEX #FFCC99
  • RGB 255, 204, 153
  • CMYK 0, 20, 40, 0

Mandarin

Bright Copper

Bright Copper is a vibrant, reddish-orange that mimics the fresh, polished surface of pure copper metal before it tarnishes. This color radiates warm conductivity, metallic sheen, and artisan craftsmanship. It suggests high energy, hand-hammered quality, and radiant warmth. Accordingly, Bright Copper is used for metallic automotive paints, contemporary cookware, and tech accessories, where it conveys a sense of modern, warm, and highly conductive brilliance.

  • HEX #FF7700
  • RGB 255, 119, 0
  • CMYK 0, 53, 100, 0

Spice

Spice is a warm, medium orange-brown that encapsulates the overall hue of a mix of ground cooking spices like cinnamon, allspice, and clove. This versatile, earthy tone is associated with aromatic warmth, culinary adventure, and homemade comfort. It represents savory richness, exotic familiarity, and welcoming kitchens. As a result, Spice is effectively utilized in food blog branding, rustic home decor, and autumn fashion, providing a grounded, warm, and subtly stimulating neutral.

  • HEX #FF8C42
  • RGB 255, 140, 66
  • CMYK 0, 45, 74, 0

Lava

Lava is an intense, glowing red-orange that mimics the molten rock erupting from a volcano, embodying primal, geologic force. This color is the ultimate representation of liquid heat, destructive creation, and untamable planetary energy. It symbolizes extreme passion, foundational power, and dangerous beauty. Consequently, Lava is used in sci-fi and fantasy visuals, extreme sports branding, and warning graphics for high heat, where it communicates an awe-inspiring and perilous level of energy.

  • HEX #CF1020
  • RGB 207, 16, 32
  • CMYK 0, 92, 85, 19

Mandarin Orange

Mandarin Orange is a vivid, cheerful orange that specifically matches the easy-peel citrus fruit, often slightly lighter and brighter than a standard orange. This color is synonymous with easy sweetness, holiday stockings (in some traditions), and accessible, juicy refreshment. It evokes feelings of simple joy, healthy snacking, and festive generosity. Therefore, Mandarin Orange is common in fruit packaging, children’s illustrations, and casual, friendly branding, projecting a wholesome and happy vibe.

  • HEX #FF8C00
  • RGB 255, 140, 0
  • CMYK 0, 45, 100, 0

Flame Orange

Flame Orange is a bright, luminous orange with strong yellow undertones, capturing the color of the hottest, most visible part of a clean-burning fire. This shade is about pure, visible heat and combustion rather than smoky reds. It symbolizes clarity of energy, visible warmth, and catalytic action. Thus, Flame Orange is often used for racing car details, high-visibility athletic gear, and cleaning product branding (suggesting powerful action), where it denotes intense, focused energy.

  • HEX #E25822
  • RGB 226, 88, 34
  • CMYK 0, 61, 85, 11

Burnt Amber

Burnt Amber describes a deep, dark orange-brown, as if the translucent golden resin of amber has been charred or deeply oxidized. This rich, somber shade combines the organic history of amber with a smoky, aged depth. It represents antiqued warmth, wisdom through trial, and resilient beauty. Accordingly, Burnt Amber is used in mystical or gothic jewelry, moody interior design accents, and dramatic landscape painting, offering a deep, complex, and ancient-seeming warmth.

  • HEX #CC5500
  • RGB 204, 85, 0
  • CMYK 0, 58, 100, 20

Coral Glow

Coral Glow is a radiant, luminous coral that seems to emit a soft, inner light, often more pink and vibrant than standard coral. This color captures the bioluminescent quality of some marine life or the flattering glow of warm light on skin. It symbolizes vibrant health, radiant joy, and ethereal warmth. Consequently, Coral Glow is a favorite in beauty product marketing for “glow” benefits, swimwear design, and uplifting graphic art, where it creates a sense of healthy, effervescent luminosity.

  • HEX #FF7F50
  • RGB 255, 127, 80
  • CMYK 0, 50, 69, 0

Amber Gold

Amber Gold is a rich, honeyed shade that blends the organic warmth of amber with the metallic prestige of gold. This color captures the essence of precious, sun-warmed resin with a gilded finish, symbolizing treasured natural beauty and refined wealth. It evokes feelings of antiqued luxury, harvested sunlight, and organic opulence. Therefore, Amber Gold is effectively used in high-end jewelry design, luxury cosmetic packaging, and autumn-themed decor, where it communicates a sense of natural, warm, and valuable elegance.

  • HEX #FFBF00
  • RGB 255, 191, 0
  • CMYK 0, 25, 100, 0

Sweet Potato

Sweet Potato is a warm, earthy orange-brown that mirrors the skin of the roasted root vegetable, offering a more rustic and muted alternative to pumpkin orange. This color is associated with wholesome nutrition, hearty comfort food, and autumnal harvests. It represents nourishing warmth, humble sustenance, and organic simplicity. Consequently, Sweet Potato is a popular choice for organic food branding, cozy home furnishings, and rustic wedding palettes, providing a grounded, comforting, and natural warmth.

  • HEX #FF8040
  • RGB 255, 128, 64
  • CMYK 0, 50, 75, 0

Tangelo

Tangelo is a vivid, reddish-orange named after the citrus hybrid of a tangerine and a pomelo or grapefruit. This specific hue is slightly deeper and more robust than a standard tangerine, capturing the fruit’s juicy, tangy character. It symbolizes bold flavor, hybrid vigor, and zesty energy. As such, Tangelo is often used in vibrant fruit juice branding, energetic sports logos, and modern digital design elements, where it makes a confident and lively statement.

  • HEX #F94D00
  • RGB 249, 77, 0
  • CMYK 0, 69, 100, 2

Cinnabar

Cinnabar is a striking vermilion red-orange, historically derived from the mercury sulfide mineral of the same name, which was ground to make the original vermilion pigment. This color is steeped in alchemical significance, ancient artistry, and symbolic importance in Asian lacquerware. It represents transformative power, traditional craftsmanship, and potent vibrancy. Accordingly, Cinnabar remains important in historical art restoration, traditional Chinese decorative arts, and as a bold accent in contemporary design.

  • HEX #E44D2E
  • RGB 228, 77, 46
  • CMYK 0, 66, 80, 11

Sun Orange

Sun Orange is a pure, brilliant orange that aims to directly represent the visible disk of the sun at midday, free from the reddening effects of sunrise or sunset. This is the archetypal color of solar energy, clarity, and life-giving power. It symbolizes centrality, radiant vitality, and unfiltered optimism. Consequently, Sun Orange is powerfully used in energy company logos, children’s drawings of the sun, and graphics representing clarity and focus, serving as the definitive emblem of solar power.

  • HEX #FF8100
  • RGB 255, 129, 0
  • CMYK 0, 49, 100, 0

Fiesta Red-Orange

Fiesta Red-Orange is a hot, vibrant shade that sits precisely on the border between red and orange, emphasizing the fiery and passionate side of the fiesta palette. This intense color is synonymous with dance, heat, and explosive celebration. It represents rhythmic passion, communal fire, and festive intensity. Thus, this hue is a key player in Latin dance costumes, festival signage, and spirited food packaging, where it delivers a powerful, hot, and exhilarating jolt of color.

  • HEX #FF5349
  • RGB 255, 83, 73
  • CMYK 0, 67, 71, 0

Autumn Leaves

Autumn Leaves is a muted, brownish-orange that captures the color of fallen leaves as they dry and curl, blending into the forest floor. This shade is less about vibrant change and more about the subdued, melancholic beauty of the season’s end. It symbolizes natural decay, peaceful transition, and earthy return. Therefore, Autumn Leaves is effectively used in naturalist branding, eco-friendly product packaging, and rustic home decor, evoking a sense of quiet, organic calm and natural cycles.

  • HEX #D98719
  • RGB 217, 135, 25
  • CMYK 0, 38, 88, 15

Papaya Orange

Papaya Orange refers to a brighter, more saturated version of the papaya fruit’s interior color, leaning more toward a true orange than a pale peach. This tropical hue captures the vibrant, juicy sweetness of the ripe fruit in its full intensity. It represents exotic vitality, juicy refreshment, and sunny exuberance. Accordingly, Papaya Orange is used in tropical print fabrics, vibrant restaurant branding, and summertime advertising, where it communicates a message of lush, healthy, and energetic enjoyment.

  • HEX #FF7518
  • RGB 255, 117, 24
  • CMYK 0, 54, 91, 0

Mango Orange

Mango Orange is a lively, golden-orange that emphasizes the orange tones in a ripe mango rather than the yellow, offering a zesty and appetizing hue. This color is all about tropical ripeness, succulent flavor, and vitamin-rich brightness. It symbolizes healthy indulgence, cheerful energy, and sunny delight. Consequently, Mango Orange is a popular choice for smoothie bar branding, beach towel designs, and playful kitchenware, where it injects a dose of fun, fruity warmth.

  • HEX #FFB347
  • RGB 255, 179, 71
  • CMYK 0, 30, 72, 0

Honey Gold

Honey Gold is a warm, luminous golden-yellow with distinct orange undertones, mirroring the color of light, liquid honey. This shade embodies natural sweetness, liquid sunshine, and sticky, precious wealth. It evokes feelings of nourishing warmth, gentle richness, and sunny abundance. As a result, Honey Gold is widely used in natural beauty products, gourmet food labels, and warm metallic finishes, where it provides a soft, rich, and inviting golden glow.

  • HEX #FBB917
  • RGB 251, 185, 23
  • CMYK 0, 26, 91, 2

Burnt Marigold

Burnt Marigold is a deep, smoky orange with brown and red undertones, as if the vibrant petals of the marigold flower have been gently singed. This color tempers the flower’s cheerful brightness with a sophisticated, autumnal depth. It symbolizes resilient beauty, seasoned warmth, and a transition from summer blaze to fall ember. Consequently, Burnt Marigold is effectively used in bohemian home decor, rustic floral arrangements, and earthy fashion palettes, where it offers a complex, warm, and slightly mysterious tone.

  • HEX #FF9933
  • RGB 255, 153, 51
  • CMYK 0, 40, 80, 0

Coral Flame

Coral Flame is a vibrant, pinkish-orange that burns with the intensity of a flame, blending the organic warmth of coral with the dynamic energy of fire. This hue is more electric and less muted than standard coral, representing passionate life, energetic beauty, and radiant heat. It suggests dramatic vibrancy, spirited attraction, and captivating warmth. Therefore, Coral Flame is a striking choice for evening gowns, cocktail branding, and contemporary art, where it commands attention with its lively, luminous quality.

  • HEX #FF6F61
  • RGB 255, 111, 97
  • CMYK 0, 56, 62, 0

Pumpkin Gold

Pumpkin Gold is a lustrous, metallic orange that combines the festive familiarity of pumpkin with the luxurious sheen of gold leaf. This color evokes harvest celebrations elevated to a level of opulence and ceremonial abundance. It represents prosperous festivity, gilded tradition, and warm grandeur. Accordingly, Pumpkin Gold is used in luxury holiday packaging, elaborate Thanksgiving table settings, and high-end seasonal decor, adding a touch of refined splendor to autumnal themes.

  • HEX #FF7F24
  • RGB 255, 127, 36
  • CMYK 0, 50, 86, 0

Tangerine Gold

Tangerine Gold is a bright, shimmering blend where the zest of tangerine is fused with a radiant gold finish, creating a sparkling, energetic metallic hue. This color captures the joy of citrus and the value of precious metal in one vibrant package. It symbolizes optimistic wealth, sunny success, and cheerful luxury. Thus, Tangerine Gold is popular for celebratory party supplies, jewelry with a modern twist, and upbeat tech product accents, where it feels both valuable and fun.

  • HEX #FFAB00
  • RGB 255, 171, 0
  • CMYK 0, 33, 100, 0

Persimmon Orange

Persimmon Orange is the definitive, saturated orange-red of a fully ripe persimmon fruit, embodying a sweetness that is deep and almost wine-like. This rich hue is associated with luscious maturity, fortunate harvests in Asian culture, and vivid, sticky sweetness. It represents ripe fulfillment, intense flavor, and vibrant cultural symbolism. Consequently, Persimmon Orange is used in Asian textile design, gourmet food presentation, and bold minimalist graphics, where it makes a statement of deep, ripe warmth.

  • HEX #EC5800
  • RGB 236, 88, 0
  • CMYK 0, 63, 100, 7

Bright Copper

Bright Copper appears again as a descriptor for a vivid, radiant copper tone, emphasizing its unoxidized, highly reflective state. This color is all about modern metallics, excellent conductivity, and a sleek, warm finish. It signifies innovation, artisan quality, and radiant energy transfer. As such, it remains a key color for contemporary architecture accents, high-performance cookware, and automotive detailing, representing a fusion of traditional material with a bright, contemporary aesthetic.

  • HEX #FF7700
  • RGB 255, 119, 0
  • CMYK 0, 53, 100, 0

Sunset Gold

Sunset Gold is a soft, diffused golden-orange that captures the last golden rays of the sun as it dips below the horizon, just before the sky explodes into reds and purples. This color embodies tranquil conclusion, gentle radiance, and peaceful closure. It symbolizes melancholic beauty, quiet reflection, and the golden hour’s magic. Therefore, Sunset Gold is effectively used in spa and wellness branding, romantic photography filters, and serene interior design, creating a calm, warm, and glowing atmosphere.

  • HEX #FF8243
  • RGB 255, 130, 67
  • CMYK 0, 49, 74, 0

Peach Gold

Peach Gold is a delicate, pale metallic hue where the softness of peach is infused with a subtle gold shimmer, creating a luxurious and flattering pastel metal. This sophisticated shade is the color of blushing warmth touched by luxury, ideal for high-end cosmetics, elegant stationery, and bridal accessories. It represents gentle opulence, romantic wealth, and subtle radiance. Accordingly, Peach Gold is favored for products and designs that aim to communicate premium quality with a soft, warm, and feminine touch.

  • HEX #FFDAB9
  • RGB 255, 218, 185
  • CMYK 0, 15, 27, 0

Ochre Orange

Ochre Orange specifies the deep, earthy orange segment of the natural ochre pigment range, a color that has adorned human artifacts for over 70,000 years. This primal hue is steeped in human history, connecting modern use to ancient cave paintings and rituals. It symbolizes earthy foundation, ancestral connection, and organic warmth. Consequently, Ochre Orange is used in historical art reproductions, ethnographic fashion, and natural pigment-based paints, maintaining a link to our most fundamental artistic and cultural roots.

  • HEX #CC7722
  • RGB 204, 119, 34
  • CMYK 0, 42, 83, 20

Golden Tangerine

Golden Tangerine is a vibrant, luminous orange with a dominant golden-yellow undertone, as if a tangerine is lit from within by sunlight. This shade amplifies the citrus fruit’s natural glow to a radiant, almost divine level. It represents sun-drenched joy, brilliant health, and effervescent vitality. Thus, Golden Tangerine is an excellent choice for vitamin and health supplement branding, energetic lifestyle imagery, and any design needing to project an aura of vibrant, positive well-being.

  • HEX #FFC000
  • RGB 255, 192, 0
  • CMYK 0, 25, 100, 0

title: Shades of Yellow: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Yellow is more than a bright color. It reflects warmth, optimism, and clarity. In this post, you will explore 100 plus shades of yellow, from soft pastel tones to deep golden hues. Each shade carries its own mood, story, and visual impact. Every color includes hex, RGB, and CMYK codes, along with its meaning and … Read more
content:
Yellow is more than a bright color. It reflects warmth, optimism, and clarity. In this post, you will explore 100 plus shades of yellow, from soft pastel tones to deep golden hues. Each shade carries its own mood, story, and visual impact.

Every color includes hex, RGB, and CMYK codes, along with its meaning and common uses. This makes it easier to choose the right yellow for design work, branding, art, or home decor. Whether you prefer a gentle butter yellow or a bold sunflower tone, the details are all here.

By the end of this guide, you will clearly understand how each yellow shade looks, feels, and functions. You can confidently select the perfect yellow that fits your creative goal.

Let’s step into the colorful world of yellow shades.

Yellow

Yellow is the pure spectral color between green and orange on the visible spectrum. Historically, one of the oldest pigments was Yellow Ochre, used in prehistoric cave art. Interestingly, it was notoriously difficult to source a bright, lasting yellow for artists’ paints. In meaning, it universally represents sunshine, happiness, and optimism. However, it also signals caution and cowardice. Therefore, its use is diverse, from cheerful branding to warning signs and taxi cabs.

  • HEX #FFFF00
  • RGB 255, 255, 0
  • CMYK 0, 0, 100, 0

Bright Yellow

Bright Yellow is an intense, highly vivid shade that commands immediate attention. Historically, its modern potency comes from chemical pigments like chrome yellow. Notably, it is one of the most visible colors to the human eye in daylight. Thus, it is fundamentally linked to warning and visibility. Consequently, it’s extensively used for highlighter pens, safety vests, and cautionary signage.

  • HEX #FFEA00
  • RGB 255, 234, 0
  • CMYK 0, 8, 100, 0

Lemon Yellow

Lemon Yellow is a light, crisp yellow with a slight greenish undertone, reminiscent of the fruit’s flesh. It became prominent with the 19th-century invention of zinc chromate pigment. This color evokes freshness, tartness, and a clean zestiness. It is less aggressive than pure yellow. As a result, Lemon Yellow is popular for summery designs, kitchen products, and refreshing beverages.

  • HEX #FAFA33
  • RGB 250, 250, 51
  • CMYK 0, 0, 80, 2

Canary Yellow

Canary Yellow is a brilliantly bright, slightly softened yellow named after the vibrant bird’s plumage. It gained fashion prominence in the 1920s for daring sportswear. This shade is inherently cheerful, energetic, and sunny. It suggests openness and warmth. Therefore, Canary Yellow is famously used in retro designs, activewear, and to create a friendly, approachable feel.

  • HEX #FFFF8F
  • RGB 255, 255, 143
  • CMYK 0, 0, 44, 0

Golden Yellow

Golden Yellow is a rich, warm yellow infused with a strong orange influence, mimicking the color of gold metal. It has always been associated with precious materials and imperial power. This color conveys wealth, success, and high quality. It feels more luxurious than basic yellow. Thus, Golden Yellow is effectively used for premium branding, awards, and festive decorations.

  • HEX #FFC000
  • RGB 255, 192, 0
  • CMYK 0, 25, 100, 0

Amber

Amber is a deep, orangey-yellow named after the fossilized tree resin. Historically, it has been prized as a gemstone for jewelry for thousands of years. This color embodies warmth, energy, and a glowing presence. It also functions as a traffic light signal for caution. Accordingly, Amber is used for decorative glassware, warning lights, and autumnal themes.

  • HEX #FFBF00
  • RGB 255, 191, 0
  • CMYK 0, 25, 100, 0

Gold

Gold is a metallic shade representing the color of the elemental metal, requiring a shimmering finish for full effect. It is one of the oldest colors associated with divinity, victory, and extreme wealth across civilizations. This color symbolizes ultimate achievement, luxury, and triumph. Consequently, Gold is reserved for medals, luxury goods, ceremonial attire, and elite branding.

  • HEX #FFD700
  • RGB 255, 215, 0
  • CMYK 0, 16, 100, 0

Mustard Yellow

Mustard Yellow is a muted, warm, and earthy dark yellow with strong brown undertones, named for the condiment. It rose to peak popularity in 1970s fashion and interior design. This color evokes autumn, vintage style, and a subdued warmth. It feels retro and grounded. Therefore, Mustard Yellow is a staple for vintage themes, rustic decor, and fall apparel.

  • HEX #FFDB58
  • RGB 255, 219, 88
  • CMYK 0, 14, 66, 0

Maize

Maize is a medium yellow with a beige undertone, directly named after the corn kernel. It is the official color of the University of Michigan. This shade represents harvest, nourishment, and simplicity. It is a natural and comforting tone. As such, Maize is used in agricultural branding, rustic designs, and academic insignia.

  • HEX #FBEC5D
  • RGB 251, 236, 93
  • CMYK 0, 6, 63, 2

Icterine

Icterine is a light, luminous yellow with a greenish tint, specifically named for its resemblance to the color of certain orioles and other birds. It is a specialist term from ornithology. The color suggests uniqueness, brightness, and a natural glow. It is vibrant yet soft. Thus, Icterine is ideal for illustrating bird plumage, fresh designs, and light accents.

  • HEX #FCF55F
  • RGB 252, 245, 95
  • CMYK 0, 3, 62, 1

Cadmium Yellow

Cadmium Yellow is a dense, opaque pigment known for its exceptional brilliance and covering power. Historically, it was developed in the 19th century as a synthetic inorganic pigment, replacing toxic alternatives like chrome yellow. This color is synonymous with artistic mastery and vibrancy. However, its production involves toxic cadmium. Therefore, it remains a prized, though sometimes replaced, color for fine artist paints and industrial plastics.

  • HEX #FDDA0D
  • RGB 253, 218, 13
  • CMYK 0, 14, 95, 1

Goldenrod

Goldenrod is a deep, warm yellow named after the wildflower. It was used as a source for yellow dye in traditional textiles. This color embodies the essence of late summer and early autumn meadows. It conveys a sense of warmth, encouragement, and growth. Consequently, Goldenrod is popular in floral designs, rustic crafts, and as a warming neutral in design.

  • HEX #DAA520
  • RGB 218, 165, 32
  • CMYK 0, 24, 85, 15

Naples Yellow

Naples Yellow is a pale, muted yellow with a beige-pink undertone. Historically, it was one of the principal pigments used by Old Masters, originally made from lead antimonate. This earthy hue is prized for painting human flesh tones and natural light. It suggests warmth, antiquity, and subtlety. Thus, Naples Yellow remains a staple on fine artists’ palettes for portraits and landscape painting.

  • HEX #FADA5E
  • RGB 250, 218, 94
  • CMYK 0, 13, 62, 2

Saffron

Saffron is a golden orange-yellow named after the valuable spice stigmas. It is historically one of the world’s most expensive colorants, used for both dye and food. This color is deeply associated with sacred rituals in Buddhism and Hinduism. It represents purity, enlightenment, and sacrifice. Accordingly, Saffron is prominent in religious robes, South Asian cuisine, and ceremonial flags.

  • HEX #F4C430
  • RGB 244, 196, 48
  • CMYK 0, 20, 80, 4

Gamboge

Gamboge is a deep, mustardy yellow-orange originating from the resin of the Garcinia tree in Southeast Asia. It was historically used as a watercolor pigment and a purgative in medicine. This rich color conveys exoticism, warmth, and intensity. It has a transparent quality in washes. Therefore, Gamboge is cherished in traditional watercolor painting and for creating warm glazes.

  • HEX #E49B0F
  • RGB 228, 155, 15
  • CMYK 0, 32, 93, 11

Citrine

Citrine is a greenish-yellow to brownish-orange shade, named after the quartz gemstone. Its name derives from the French word “citron” for lemon. This color is believed to carry the energy of sunshine and prosperity in crystal healing. It feels both luminous and earthy.
