Citrus Yellow is a zesty, slightly green-tinged yellow reminiscent of lemons and limes. It is a sharp, tangy, and refreshing hue. This color evokes vitality, acidity, and wakefulness. It stimulates the senses and appetite. Therefore, Citrus Yellow is prevalent in beverage packaging, cleaning product branding, and summer fashion to convey freshness.

  • HEX #FFE44D
  • RGB 255, 228, 77
  • CMYK 0, 11, 70, 0

Sunny Yellow

Sunny Yellow is a cheerful, warm yellow that is bright but not overpowering. It is the universal shorthand for a pleasant, cloudless day. This color represents uncomplicated happiness, optimism, and friendliness. It is approachable and classic. Accordingly, Sunny Yellow is a favorite for children’s toys, cheerful home decor, and welcoming retail displays.

  • HEX #FFE066
  • RGB 255, 224, 102
  • CMYK 0, 12, 60, 0

Pale Lemon

Pale Lemon is a very light, washed-out version of lemon yellow with a whitened quality. It is a delicate, airy, and soft pastel. This shade suggests subtlety, freshness, and a gentle brightness. It is less tart than true lemon. Thus, Pale Lemon is used for spring wedding palettes, beachy interiors, and soft cosmetic packaging.

  • HEX #FFF44F
  • RGB 255, 244, 79
  • CMYK 0, 4, 69, 0

Golden Sand

Golden Sand is a muted, medium yellow with significant brown undertones, resembling sunlit desert sand. It is a warm, earthy, and natural neutral. This color evokes warmth, dryness, and exotic landscapes. It provides a stable, sunny base. Consequently, Golden Sand is ideal for camouflage patterns, travel branding, and earthy interior design schemes.

  • HEX #E6C35C
  • RGB 230, 195, 92
  • CMYK 0, 15, 60, 10

Dusty Yellow

Dusty Yellow is a medium yellow softened with a gray or beige overlay, as if covered by a thin layer of dust. It is a vintage, muted, and sophisticated shade. This color suggests age, calmness, and a weathered elegance. It tones down yellow’s energy. Therefore, Dusty Yellow is popular in shabby chic decor, historical fiction book covers, and muted fashion collections.

  • HEX #D2B55B
  • RGB 210, 181, 91
  • CMYK 0, 14, 57, 18

Muted Yellow

Muted Yellow is a general term for any yellow whose saturation has been significantly reduced, often with complementary colors. It is a subtle, complex, and artistic hue. This color conveys quiet wisdom, autumnal feeling, and nuanced optimism. It is more wearable than pure yellow. Thus, Muted Yellow is used in landscape painting, sophisticated apparel, and elegant home furnishings.

  • HEX #D8C35A
  • RGB 216, 195, 90
  • CMYK 0, 10, 58, 15

Clay Yellow

Clay Yellow is a warm, earthy beige-yellow, directly referencing natural pottery clay or adobe. It is a organic, handcrafted, and rustic color. This hue embodies earthiness, simplicity, and human craftsmanship. It feels grounded and natural. Accordingly, Clay Yellow is fundamental in artisanal branding, southwestern architecture, and natural textile dyes.

  • HEX #D2B48C
  • RGB 210, 180, 140
  • CMYK 0, 14, 33, 18

Yellow Tan

Yellow Tan is a light, warm brown with a dominant yellow undertone, similar to tanned leather. It is a classic, rugged, and outdoor-associated neutral. This color suggests durability, adventure, and natural wear. It is a versatile, warm background. Consequently, Yellow Tan is used for work boots, safari gear, outdoor equipment, and vintage leather goods.

  • HEX #FFE4B5
  • RGB 255, 228, 181
  • CMYK 0, 11, 29, 0

Antique Cream

Antique Cream is a warm, yellowish off-white with a subtle gray or brown tint, resembling aged ivory or old parchment. It is softer and warmer than stark white. This color evokes heritage, authenticity, and gentle aging. It adds instant vintage character. Therefore, Antique Cream is used for historical document reproductions, classic interior trim, and vintage linen finishes.

  • HEX #FBF3C1
  • RGB 251, 243, 193
  • CMYK 0, 3, 23, 2

Golden Beige

Golden Beige is a rich beige with strong, warm yellow undertones, giving it a luminous quality. It is a luxurious and warm neutral. This shade represents understated elegance, natural warmth, and sophistication. It is more dynamic than basic beige. Thus, Golden Beige is favored for high-end interior design, quality leather goods, and neutral fashion with a touch of glamour.

  • HEX #E5C07B
  • RGB 229, 192, 123
  • CMYK 0, 16, 46, 10

Sunwashed Yellow

Sunwashed Yellow is a very pale, bleached-out yellow, as if faded by long exposure to sunlight. It is a soft, dreamy, and weathered pastel. This color suggests memory, nostalgia, and gentle warmth. It has a relaxed, coastal feel. Consequently, Sunwashed Yellow is ideal for beach house decor, faded denim, and relaxed summer branding.

  • HEX #FFF4B8
  • RGB 255, 244, 184
  • CMYK 0, 4, 28, 0

Golden Haze

Golden Haze is a light, muted yellow with a dusty, ethereal quality, like sunlight seen through mist or pollen. It is a romantic and soft-focus shade. This hue embodies dreaminess, soft light, and a magical glow. It is less defined than solid yellows. Therefore, Golden Haze is used in ethereal wedding themes, perfume packaging, and poetic landscape illustrations.

  • HEX #F2D974
  • RGB 242, 217, 116
  • CMYK 0, 10, 52, 5

Pale Harvest

Pale Harvest is a very light, delicate yellow with a hint of beige, like the first light on harvested grain. It is a soft, hopeful, and gentle autumnal color. This shade conveys abundance without heaviness, and a delicate transition. It is a subtle seasonal nod. Accordingly, Pale Harvest is used for early fall collections, gentle home accents, and soft food photography backgrounds.

  • HEX #F7E7A9
  • RGB 247, 231, 169
  • CMYK 0, 6, 32, 3

Soft Sun

Soft Sun is a pale, creamy yellow that embodies the gentle warmth of morning sunlight. It is a nurturing and comforting pastel. This color promotes calm optimism, clarity, and a gentle awakening. It is non-aggressive and soothing. Thus, Soft Sun is perfect for hospitality spaces, wellness blogs, and baby bedding for a sunny, serene feel.

  • HEX #FFF3A0
  • RGB 255, 243, 160
  • CMYK 0, 5, 37, 0

Meadow Yellow

Meadow Yellow is a light, green-tinged yellow reminiscent of buttercups and dandelions in a field. It is a fresh, natural, and lively pastel. This hue suggests open spaces, springtime, and simple joys. It feels organic and free. Consequently, Meadow Yellow is used for garden center branding, natural skincare products, and cheerful casual wear.

  • HEX #ECE68A
  • RGB 236, 230, 138
  • CMYK 0, 3, 42, 7

Pale Banana

Pale Banana is a light, creamy yellow, a desaturated version of the fruit’s peel. It is a sweet, soft, and slightly whimsical shade. This color evokes mild sweetness, approachability, and a touch of fun. It is less bold than banana yellow. Therefore, Pale Banana is common in children’s decor, soft furnishings, and friendly food packaging for mild flavors.

  • HEX #FBE7B2
  • RGB 251, 231, 178
  • CMYK 0, 8, 29, 2

Light Marigold

Light Marigold is a softened, pastel version of the vibrant flower, with a warm, peachy-yellow tone. It is a cheerful yet gentle and sophisticated hue. This color blends warmth with softness, suggesting joy without intensity. It is versatile and uplifting. Accordingly, Light Marigold is used in spring floral arrangements, feminine fashion, and welcoming interior accents.

  • HEX #F9E076
  • RGB 249, 224, 118
  • CMYK 0, 10, 53, 2

Honeycomb Yellow

Honeycomb Yellow is a warm, golden amber with a slightly opaque, waxy quality, like raw honeycomb. It is a rich, textured, and natural shade. This color embodies sweetness, intricate natural structure, and golden nourishment. It feels organic and precious. Thus, Honeycomb Yellow is used in apiary branding, artisanal product labels, and warm, tactile design elements.

  • HEX #E8AC41
  • RGB 232, 172, 65
  • CMYK 0, 26, 72, 9

Warm Sand

Warm Sand is a pale, peachy-yellow beige that captures the color of sunlit beach sand. It is a universal, calming, and warm neutral. This shade suggests relaxation, holidays, and natural simplicity. It is slightly more colorful than basic beige. Consequently, Warm Sand is a go-to for resort wear, coastal interior design, and background textures in web design.

  • HEX #F4E1A1
  • RGB 244, 225, 161
  • CMYK 0, 8, 34, 4

Golden Straw

Golden Straw is a bright, warm yellow with a distinct golden sheen, like sun-bleached straw. It is a rustic, radiant, and pastoral color. This hue represents harvest light, rural idyll, and natural abundance. It is more vibrant than plain straw. Therefore, Golden Straw is effective for farmers’ market branding, rustic wedding decor, and folk art motifs.

  • HEX #E9D66B
  • RGB 233, 214, 107
  • CMYK 0, 8, 54, 9

Desert Sun

Desert Sun is a strong, orangey-yellow that mimics the intense, glaring sun over arid landscapes. It is a harsh, powerful, and dramatic hue. This color conveys extreme heat, survival, and stark beauty. It is intense and commanding. Thus, Desert Sun is used in adventure sports branding, dramatic landscape art, and packaging for strong, bold products.

  • HEX #E1AD01
  • RGB 225, 173, 1
  • CMYK 0, 23, 100, 12

Vintage Yellow

Vintage Yellow is a muted, medium yellow with olive or brown undertones, reminiscent of aged photographs or old posters. It is a deliberately antiqued and nostalgic shade. This color evokes memory, history, and a softened past. It instantly creates a retro feel. Accordingly, Vintage Yellow is popular in antique store signage, retro product revivals, and period film grading.

  • HEX #D6C537
  • RGB 214, 197, 55
  • CMYK 0, 8, 74, 16

Soft Gold

Soft Gold is a pale, muted metallic yellow with low saturation, lacking the brilliance of true gold. It is a subtle, elegant, and understated metallic. This color suggests quiet luxury, aged treasure, and delicate shine. It is more wearable than bright gold. Consequently, Soft Gold is used for jewelry for daytime, elegant wedding invitations, and sophisticated metallic accents in design.

  • HEX #EEDC90
  • RGB 238, 220, 144
  • CMYK 0, 8, 39, 7

Pale Honey

Pale Honey is a very light, translucent yellow-beige, resembling diluted, clear honey. It is a gentle, sweet, and luminous neutral. This shade embodies delicate sweetness, light, and purity. It is warm and inviting. Therefore, Pale Honey is ideal for natural beauty product packaging, light-filled interior spaces, and soft fabric dyes.

  • HEX #FAF3B0
  • RGB 250, 243, 176
  • CMYK 0, 3, 30, 2

Antique Straw

Antique Straw is a grayish, dull yellow with a greenish hint, like very old, dried straw. It is a subdued, historical, and earthy color. This hue suggests age, weathering, and humble materials. It is a quiet, complex neutral. Thus, Antique Straw is used in historical reenactment garb, museum dioramas, and traditional craftworks aiming for authenticity.

  • HEX #E6D690
  • RGB 230, 214, 144
  • CMYK 0, 7, 37, 10

Golden Mist

Golden Mist is a light, ethereal yellow with a grayish or whitened overlay, like sunlight diffused through morning fog. It is a dreamy, soft, and mysterious pastel. This color conveys ambiguity, soft light, and a magical atmosphere. It is less definite than solid yellows. Accordingly, Golden Mist is perfect for fantasy art, perfume advertisements, and serene, abstract backgrounds.

  • HEX #EEDD82
  • RGB 238, 221, 130
  • CMYK 0, 7, 45, 7

Sunlit Yellow

Sunlit Yellow is a clear, bright medium yellow that captures the effect of direct sunlight on a white surface. It is a pure, clean, and cheerful hue. This color embodies direct illumination, clarity, and unabashed happiness. It is neither green nor orange toned. Thus, Sunlit Yellow is used for energizing brand logos, cheerful packaging, and designs meant to feel instantly positive and clear.

  • HEX #FFE87C
  • RGB 255, 232, 124
  • CMYK 0, 9, 51, 0

Tropical Yellow

Tropical Yellow is a warm, saturated yellow with a distinct orange pull, evoking exotic flowers and sun-drenched beaches. It is a hot, vibrant, and vacation-inspired shade. This color suggests escapism, heat, and lush vibrancy. It is more intense than standard sunny yellow. Consequently, Tropical Yellow is favored for tourist marketing, tropical print fabrics, and vibrant cocktail branding.

  • HEX #FFC87C
  • RGB 255, 200, 124
  • CMYK 0, 22, 51, 0

Golden Amber

Golden Amber is a rich, orange-yellow that sits between amber and gold, resembling the gemstone’s warm glow. It is a dense, luminous, and precious hue. This color represents captured sunlight, fossilized energy, and deep warmth. It has a timeless, organic quality. Therefore, Golden Amber is used in jewelry design, luxury cosmetic cases, and packaging for premium spirits.

  • HEX #FFB000
  • RGB 255, 176, 0
  • CMYK 0, 31, 100, 0

Mellow Yellow

Mellow Yellow is a soft, medium yellow with a brownish or grayish undertone, creating a relaxed, subdued effect. It is a calm, gentle, and retro shade famously referenced in song. This color evokes laid-back vibes, the 1970s, and softened optimism. It is easy on the eyes. Accordingly, Mellow Yellow is ideal for coffee shop interiors, indie music album art, and bohemian home decor.

  • HEX #F8DE88
  • RGB 248, 222, 136
  • CMYK 0, 10, 45, 3

Pale Sun Yellow

Pale Sun Yellow is an extremely light, whitened yellow, like the sun’s corona or early morning light. It is an ethereal, airy, and delicate pastel. This shade suggests dawn, fragility, and the first hint of warmth. It is almost an off-white with a yellow promise. Thus, Pale Sun Yellow is used for angelic or heavenly themes, delicate wedding dresses, and soft background washes in painting.

  • HEX #FFF9AE
  • RGB 255, 249, 174
  • CMYK 0, 2, 32, 0

Golden Wheat

Golden Wheat is a warm, muted yellow with strong beige undertones, directly matching ripe wheat fields at harvest. It is a natural, abundant, and comforting neutral. This color embodies sustenance, the earth’s bounty, and rustic beauty. It is a classic, versatile hue. Consequently, Golden Wheat is prevalent in organic food branding, rural tourism marketing, and cozy autumnal fashion.

  • HEX #EACF7A
  • RGB 234, 207, 122
  • CMYK 0, 12, 48, 8

title: Shades of Blue: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Blue is more than a calming color. It reflects depth, trust, and emotion. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of blue, from soft sky tones to deep navy hues, with each shade carrying its own mood and story. You will find hex, RGB, and CMYK codes for every color. You will also … Read more
content:
Blue is more than a calming color. It reflects depth, trust, and emotion. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of blue, from soft sky tones to deep navy hues, with each shade carrying its own mood and story.

You will find hex, RGB, and CMYK codes for every color. You will also learn the meaning and common uses of each shade, which helps when choosing blue for design, art, branding, or interior spaces.

By the end of this guide, you will clearly see how each blue looks, feels, and functions, making it easier to select the right shade for your next project.

Welcome to the definitive exploration of blue, where every shade has a story and a purpose.

Aqua

Aqua is a vibrant, electric cyan-blue that sits precisely between green and blue on the spectrum. Its name originates from the Latin word for water. Historically, it was one of the first web colors formulated for early computer displays. Aqua is synonymous with freshness, vitality, and digital clarity. Therefore, it is widely used in website design, pool and spa branding, and summer-themed graphics to evoke a crisp, refreshing feel.

  • HEX #00FFFF
  • RGB 0, 255, 255
  • CMYK 100, 0, 0, 0

Azure

Azure is a pale, almost ethereal cyan-blue reminiscent of a clear, cloudless sky. The name is derived from the intense blue mineral lapis lazuli. Historically, it was a prized pigment in heraldry and art. This color conveys calm, openness, and infinite possibility. Thus, Azure is frequently employed in corporate logos, healthcare interiors, and cloud technology branding to suggest transparency and trust.

  • HEX #F0FFFF
  • RGB 240, 255, 255
  • CMYK 6, 0, 0, 0

Baby Blue

Baby Blue is a very pale tint of blue with soft, gentle undertones. It gained popularity in the Western world during the 1940s as a color for baby boys. This shade represents innocence, tranquility, and tenderness. Consequently, it is a staple in nursery decor, baby product packaging, and soft spring fashion collections, offering a soothing and delicate visual cue.

  • HEX #89CFF0
  • RGB 137, 207, 240
  • CMYK 43, 14, 0, 6

Blue

Blue, in its purest form, is a primary color with a dominant wavelength between 450 and 495 nanometres. It has been significant throughout art history, notably in ultramarine pigment from lapis lazuli. This fundamental color symbolizes trust, stability, and depth. As a result, it is ubiquitously used in corporate identities, police uniforms, and national flags to project authority and reliability.

  • HEX #0000FF
  • RGB 0, 0, 255
  • CMYK 100, 100, 0, 0

Blue Gray

Blue Gray is a cool, desaturated blend of blue and gray, evoking weathered stone or a dusky sky. It became prominent in interior design during the 18th century. This color embodies sobriety, neutrality, and timelessness. Hence, it is a popular choice for modern minimalist interiors, sophisticated suiting fabrics, and tech product casings, providing a quiet, professional backdrop.

  • HEX #7393B3
  • RGB 115, 147, 179
  • CMYK 36, 18, 0, 30

Blue Green

Blue Green is a deep, rich cyan shade leaning more toward green, reminiscent of tropical ocean waters. It is closely related to the color teal. Historically, it was difficult to produce as a stable dye. This color signifies clarity, sophistication, and emotional balance. Accordingly, it is effective in spa branding, resort wear, and environmental organization logos to communicate renewal and depth.

  • HEX #088F8F
  • RGB 8, 143, 143
  • CMYK 94, 0, 0, 44

Bright Blue

Bright Blue is an intense, high-energy shade with strong visual impact. It is a modern color often associated with synthetic pigments. This hue represents vibrancy, confidence, and innovation. Therefore, it is commonly seen in sports team uniforms, energetic advertising, and children’s toys, where it commands attention and conveys dynamism.

  • HEX #0096FF
  • RGB 0, 150, 255
  • CMYK 100, 41, 0, 0

Cadet Blue

Cadet Blue is a muted, grayish-blue that was first used in the 19th century for military cadet uniforms, particularly in the United States. It carries a sense of discipline, tradition, and modesty. Thus, it is used in military academies, classic workwear, and heritage brand designs to evoke a sense of orderly and dependable service.

  • HEX #5F9EA0
  • RGB 95, 158, 160
  • CMYK 41, 1, 0, 37

Cobalt Blue

Cobalt Blue is a vivid, saturated shade that has been valued since the 8th century for use in Chinese porcelain. The modern pigment was discovered in 1802 by Louis Jacques Thénard. This intense color symbolizes integrity, insight, and bold expression. Consequently, it is prized in fine art pottery, high-fashion garments, and as an accent in interior design for its striking, clean appearance.

  • HEX #0047AB
  • RGB 0, 71, 171
  • CMYK 100, 58, 0, 33

Cornflower Blue

Cornflower Blue is a soft, light to medium blue named after the vibrant flower Centaurea cyanus. It was famously a favorite color of Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer. This hue represents serenity, delicacy, and hope. As a result, it is often used in wedding themes, floral arrangements, and web design to create a friendly, peaceful, and inviting atmosphere.

  • HEX #6495ED
  • RGB 100, 149, 237
  • CMYK 58, 37, 0, 7

Dark Blue

Dark Blue is a deep, intense shade almost indistinguishable from black in low light. Historically, it was expensive to produce, making it a color of status and power for centuries. This color conveys authority, intelligence, and stability. Consequently, it is a cornerstone of professional business suits, formal evening wear, and luxury automotive finishes, projecting an image of seriousness and reliability.

  • HEX #00008B
  • RGB 0, 0, 139
  • CMYK 100, 100, 0, 45

Denim

Denim is a moderate blue with subtle gray undertones, directly named after the durable cotton twill fabric. It originated in Nîmes, France (“de Nîmes”). This color represents durability, casual comfort, and timeless style. Thus, it is globally synonymous with blue jeans, workwear fashion, and casual American culture, embodying a rugged and versatile aesthetic.

  • HEX #6F8FAF
  • RGB 111, 143, 175
  • CMYK 37, 18, 0, 31

Egyptian Blue

Egyptian Blue is a rich, ancient pigment first synthesized in ancient Egypt over 4,000 years ago, making it one of the earliest synthetic colors. It was used in tomb paintings and artifacts. This historical color signifies sacredness, the divine, and technological ingenuity. Accordingly, it appears in historical recreations, art restoration, and designs seeking an archaic, mystical feel.

  • HEX #1434A4
  • RGB 20, 52, 164
  • CMYK 88, 68, 0, 36

Electric Blue

Electric Blue is a brilliant, stark cyan that seems to glow, mimicking the color of ionized argon gas. It is a distinctly modern, synthetic color. This vibrant hue represents high energy, futurism, and technological advancement. Therefore, it is frequently used in sci-fi themes, neon lighting, and athletic wear to create a shocking, attention-grabbing visual effect.

  • HEX #7DF9FF
  • RGB 125, 249, 255
  • CMYK 51, 2, 0, 0

Glaucous

Glaucous is a grayish-blue or slate color, often used to describe the powdery coating on grapes or plums. The name comes from the Latin “glaucus,” meaning bluish-gray. This muted shade evokes subtlety, maturity, and a natural, weathered quality. Hence, it is used in botanical illustrations, sophisticated muted palettes, and heritage brand packaging to convey understated elegance.

  • HEX #6082B6
  • RGB 96, 130, 182
  • CMYK 47, 29, 0, 29

Indigo

Indigo is a deep, rich color between blue and violet on the spectrum. For centuries, it was a precious dye extracted from plants of the genus Indigofera, traded along the Silk Road. This color symbolizes wisdom, intuition, and spiritual depth. Consequently, it is central to denim dyeing, traditional textiles worldwide, and spiritual imagery, representing both the tangible and the mystical.

  • HEX #3F00FF
  • RGB 63, 0, 255
  • CMYK 75, 100, 0, 0

Iris

Iris is a bright, vibrant purplish-blue named after the flower of the same name. It is closely related to the color of the iris in the human eye. This luminous color conveys royalty, eloquence, and cherished friendship. Consequently, Mint Blue is popular in bathroom decor, vintage dress design, and confectionery packaging, offering a crisp, soothing, and slightly nostalgic aesthetic.

  • HEX #429E9D
  • RGB 66, 158, 157
  • CMYK 58, 0, 1, 38

Cyan Blue

Cyan Blue is a pure, vibrant secondary color, precisely halfway between green and blue on the additive RGB model. It is one of the primary colors in printing. This electric shade represents clarity, communication, and technological precision. Thus, Cyan Blue is fundamental in color process printing, digital design interfaces, and medical imaging, serving as a key component for creating a full spectrum of color.

  • HEX #00FFFF
  • RGB 0, 255, 255
  • CMYK 100, 0, 0, 0

Blissful Blue (generic pastel)

Blissful Blue is a soft, milky light blue with gentle gray undertones, falling into the category of comforting pastels. It is designed to evoke a serene emotional response. This calming shade represents tranquil happiness, soft comfort, and peaceful daydreams. Consequently, Blissful Blue is effectively used in bedroom linens, meditation app backgrounds, and baby care products to promote relaxation and a sense of gentle well-being.

  • HEX #B3CEE5
  • RGB 179, 206, 229
  • CMYK 22, 10, 0, 10

Columbia Blue

Columbia Blue is a light, powdery azure associated with Columbia University and other academic institutions. It is a sporty, energetic pastel. This vibrant shade signifies academic spirit, youthful vitality, and clear aspiration. Therefore, Columbia Blue is prominently featured in college sports uniforms, vintage-style branding, and spring fashion collections, fostering a sense of community and fresh energy.

  • HEX #9BDDFF
  • RGB 155, 221, 255
  • CMYK 39, 13, 0, 0

Serenity Blue

Serenity Blue is a pale, cool gray-blue, one of the Pantone Colors of the Year for 2016 alongside Rose Quartz. It was chosen to reflect mindfulness and well-being. This quiet hue embodies peace, stability, and mental respite. Accordingly, Serenity Blue is widely adopted in wellness marketing, gender-neutral nursery themes, and modern minimalist decor, providing a visual sanctuary from overstimulation.

  • HEX #B3CEE5
  • RGB 179, 206, 229
  • CMYK 22, 10, 0, 10

Sky Blue (Eggradients)

This Sky Blue variant is a bright, clear cyan-blue, virtually identical to the standard Deep Sky Blue. It captures the essence of a brilliant, cloudless day. This uplifting color represents optimism, boundless horizons, and digital friendliness. Hence, Sky Blue is a versatile choice for travel blog graphics, social media icons, and cheerful product packaging to invoke feelings of freedom and positivity.

  • HEX #00BFFF
  • RGB 0, 191, 255
  • CMYK 100, 25, 0, 0

Robin Egg Blue (Eggradients)

This Robin Egg Blue is a bright, slightly green-tinged cyan, emphasizing the fresh, crisp quality of the eggshell. It is a color of new beginnings. This lively shade symbolizes renewal, springtime, and playful elegance. Consequently, Robin Egg Blue is popular in Easter decorations, modern wedding palettes, and boutique branding, offering a chic and cheerful alternative to traditional pastels.

  • HEX #1FCECB
  • RGB 31, 206, 203
  • CMYK 85, 0, 2, 19

Misty Blue

Misty Blue is a light, hazy gray-blue that resembles a distant horizon veiled in fog. It has a soft, diffused quality. This ethereal color evokes melancholy, mystery, and soft focus. Thus, Misty Blue is ideal for poetic book covers, landscape photography titles, and linen fabric dyes, creating a mood of gentle nostalgia and quiet, atmospheric beauty.

  • HEX #B5C7EB
  • RGB 181, 199, 235
  • CMYK 23, 15, 0, 8

Sea Blue

Sea Blue is a dark, greenish-blue reminiscent of deep ocean waters. It is a natural, profound color. This powerful shade represents depth, stability, and professional maritime tradition. Accordingly, Sea Blue is commonly used in naval uniforms, marine engineering logos, and nautical-themed interiors, symbolizing the vast, reliable, and sometimes mysterious nature of the sea.

  • HEX #006994
  • RGB 0, 105, 148
  • CMYK 100, 29, 0, 42

Bahama Blue

Bahama Blue is a vivid, tropical turquoise that captures the stunning shallow waters of the Caribbean. It is an intensely inviting hue. This vibrant color signifies escape, paradise, and aquatic adventure. Therefore, Bahama Blue is quintessential for travel posters, swimwear lines, and tropical resort branding, instantly evoking a sense of warm, crystal-clear waters and leisure.

  • HEX #016396
  • RGB 1, 99, 150
  • CMYK 99, 34, 0, 41

Stratos Blue

Stratos Blue is an extremely dark navy, named after the stratosphere, representing the deep blue of the upper atmosphere. It is almost black. This profound shade embodies limitless depth, the unknown, and scientific exploration. Consequently, Stratos Blue is used in aerospace company branding, high-tech product design, and astronomy software interfaces, suggesting cutting-edge technology and infinite space.

  • HEX #00073F
  • RGB 0, 7, 63
  • CMYK 100, 89, 0, 75

True Navy Blue

True Navy Blue is the definitive, very dark blue historically used by navies worldwide. It is the standard against which other navies are measured. This authoritative color represents discipline, duty, and timeless formality. Thus, True Navy Blue is a foundation for corporate uniforms, classic tailoring, and professional accessories, offering a versatile and universally respected dark neutral.

  • HEX #000080
  • RGB 0, 0, 128
  • CMYK 100, 100, 0, 50

Deep Blue

Deep Blue is an incredibly dark, saturated blue that borders on black, reminiscent of the profound depths of the ocean or outer space. It is the essence of blue at its most intense. This mysterious shade symbolizes the unknown, profound depth, and introspective thought. Consequently, Deep Blue is used in luxury watch dials, high-end electronics, and avant-garde fashion to create a sense of sophisticated, infinite mystery.

  • HEX #050372
  • RGB 5, 3, 114
  • CMYK 96, 97, 0, 55

Persian Indigo

Persian Indigo is a deep, vibrant purplish-blue, historically a dye derived from the indigo plant in the Persian region. It is richer and redder than standard indigo. This opulent color represents spiritual wisdom, royal luxury, and exotic trade. Accordingly, Persian Indigo is found in traditional Persian textiles, ornate manuscript illumination, and bohemian decor, evoking a sense of ancient, traveled splendor.

  • HEX #603FEF
  • RGB 96, 63, 239
  • CMYK 60, 74, 0, 6

Neon Blue (Eggradients)

This Neon Blue is a bright, electric purplish-blue with a glowing, synthetic quality. It is a digital-age color meant to mimic LED lighting. This high-energy hue signifies futurism, nightlife, and hyper-stimulation. Therefore, Neon Blue is dominant in club graphics, sci-fi video game interfaces, and attention-grabbing streetwear, creating an unmistakable vibe of modern, electrified cool.

  • HEX #4D4DFF
  • RGB 77, 77, 255
  • CMYK 70, 70, 0, 0

Cerulean Blue

Cerulean Blue is a serene, medium sky-blue pigment first created in the 19th century and prized for its stability. Its name derives from the Latin for “sky.” This clear, peaceful color represents openness, clarity, and heavenly calm. Thus, Cerulean Blue is a favorite in landscape painting, fashion design (notably in the film The Devil Wears Prada), and tranquil brand identities, suggesting limitless possibility and peace.

  • HEX #2A52BE
  • RGB 42, 82, 190
  • CMYK 78, 57, 0, 25

Tiffany Blue (alternate)

This Tiffany Blue is a slightly more green-leaning variant of the iconic jewelry brand color. It retains the same luxurious and exclusive connotations. This specific shade symbolizes refined taste, romantic gift-giving, and branded luxury. Consequently, this Tiffany Blue is carefully protected in trademarked branding, high-end wedding aesthetics, and premium lifestyle marketing, representing an instantly recognizable standard of elegance.

  • HEX #0ABAB5
  • RGB 10, 186, 181
  • CMYK 95, 0, 3, 27

Ice Blue

Ice Blue is an extremely pale, whitish blue with a faint green-gray tint, mimicking the color of glacial ice. It is a cold, clean pastel. This frigid shade evokes purity, crisp cold, and sleek modernity. Hence, Ice Blue is effective for winter cosmetic packaging, high-tech appliance finishes, and spa environments, promoting a feeling of sterile cleanliness and cool refreshment.

  • HEX #DAF4F0
  • RGB 218, 244, 240
  • CMYK 11, 0, 2, 4

Seasalt Blue

Seasalt Blue is a soft, grayish light blue with a weathered, organic feel, like sun-bleached sea salt. It is a gentle, neutral-leaning pastel. This subtle color represents relaxed coastal living, understated style, and natural texture. Accordingly, Seasalt Blue is popular in beach house interiors, linen clothing, and artisanal ceramic glazes, offering a soothing, neutral backdrop with a hint of coastal charm.

  • HEX #CFE5F3
  • RGB 207, 229, 243
  • CMYK 15, 6, 0, 5

Azure Mist

Azure Mist is a very light, whitish tint of azure, so pale it is often perceived as an off-white with a blue hint. It is the faintest whisper of sky color. This ethereal shade suggests delicacy, emptiness, and a clean start. Therefore, Azure Mist is used as a wall color in galleries, background for delicate typography, and in minimalist design to create a sense of spacious, light-filled calm.

  • HEX #F0FFFF
  • RGB 240, 255, 255
  • CMYK 6, 0, 0, 0

Pale Cornflower Blue

Pale Cornflower Blue is a light, washed-out version of the classic cornflower hue, with a gentle, nostalgic quality. It is softer and more muted than its parent color. This tender shade evokes childhood memories, soft romance, and gentle reassurance. Consequently, Pale Cornflower Blue is chosen for vintage floral patterns, baby announcement cards, and soothing website themes, providing a friendly and comforting visual.

  • HEX #ABCDEF
  • RGB 171, 205, 239
  • CMYK 28, 14, 0, 6

Maya Blue Light

Maya Blue Light is a pale, ethereal version of the historical Maya Blue pigment. It retains the unique cyan character but in a much softer, airier form. This lightened ancient color represents heritage reimagined, spiritual lightness, and celestial connection. Thus, Maya Blue Light is suitable for bohemian fashion, spiritual wellness branding, and artistic wall murals, blending historical depth with a contemporary, airy feel.

  • HEX #A7C6ED
  • RGB 167, 198, 237
  • CMYK 30, 16, 0, 7

Glacial Ice

Glacial Ice is a pale, cool blue-white with a very subtle greenish-gray undertone, directly inspired by the dense, compressed ice of glaciers. It is a color of pristine cold. This frigid shade evokes pure clarity, untouched nature, and serene stillness. Consequently, Glacial Ice is used in environmental campaigns, winter skincare packaging, and modern architectural accents to convey a sense of clean, powerful, and majestic coolness.

  • HEX #DAF4F0
  • RGB 218, 244, 240
  • CMYK 11, 0, 2, 4

Light Blue (alternate)

This Light Blue is a standard pale tint of blue, functionally identical to the classic web color. It is a universally recognized pastel blue. This soft, familiar shade represents calmness, simplicity, and gentle communication. Therefore, Light Blue remains a perennial choice for hospital gowns, social media interface elements, and spring catalog backgrounds, providing an inoffensive and soothing visual field.

  • HEX #ADD8E6
  • RGB 173, 216, 230
  • CMYK 25, 6, 0, 10

Deep Sky Blue (alt)

This Deep Sky Blue is a bright, intense cyan variant, virtually identical to the standard web color. It captures the most vibrant part of a clear midday sky. This energetic hue signifies vitality, openness, and digital vibrancy. Accordingly, Deep Sky Blue is a go-to for sports team graphics, refreshing beverage advertising, and call-to-action buttons, demanding attention with its cheerful and clear intensity.

  • HEX #87D0FD
  • RGB 135, 208, 253
  • CMYK 47, 18, 0, 1

Persian Blue (alternate)

This Persian Blue is a brighter, more medium-toned azure variation of the traditional deep Persian shade. It retains a regal and artistic feel. This luminous color represents cultural richness, artistic expression, and clear communication. Hence, Persian Blue is effective in modern ethnic-inspired design, vibrant tilework, and creative studio logos, bridging historical elegance with contemporary brightness.

  • HEX #3185FC
  • RGB 49, 133, 252
  • CMYK 81, 47, 0, 1

Soft Pastel Blue

Soft Pastel Blue is a muted, gentle blue with significant gray influence, creating a dusty, quiet appearance. It sits firmly in the modern pastel spectrum. This understated shade evokes gentle comfort, muted nostalgia, and serene simplicity. Thus, Soft Pastel Blue is popular for cozy knitwear, nursery wall colors, and minimalist website headers, offering a quiet and sophisticated sense of calm.

  • HEX #ADBDFF
  • RGB 173, 189, 255
  • CMYK 32, 26, 0, 0

Oxford Blue (alternate)

This Oxford Blue is the same deep, authoritative blue-black associated with the university. It is a color of definitive tradition and formality. This profound shade symbolizes academic rigor, historic prestige, and solemn authority. Consequently, Oxford Blue is consistently used for legal robe trim, luxury pen finishes, and formal invitation lettering, representing unwavering excellence and tradition.

  • HEX #002147
  • RGB 0, 33, 71
  • CMYK 100, 54, 0, 72

Sapphire Blue (bright)

This Sapphire Blue is a vivid, medium-dark blue, matching the standard jewel tone. It is a saturated and luxurious color. This radiant shade represents truth, nobility, and valuable brilliance. Therefore, Sapphire Blue is a prime choice for logo design for trusted corporations, elegant packaging, and formal accessories, projecting an image of reliability, luxury, and clear-mindedness.

  • HEX #0F52BA
  • RGB 15, 82, 186
  • CMYK 92, 56, 0, 27

True Azure

True Azure is a vibrant, pure blue midway between azure and cobalt, embodying the ideal of a perfect sky blue. It is a color of brilliant clarity. This definitive shade signifies honesty, vivid expression, and unwavering spirit. Accordingly, True Azure is powerful in national symbolism, athletic team colors, and bold artistic statements, serving as a pure and confident expression of blue.

  • HEX #007FFF
  • RGB 0, 127, 255
  • CMYK 100, 50, 0, 0

Navy Indigo

Navy Indigo is a very dark blue with a slight violet undertone, merging the concepts of navy and indigo into a deep, rich hue. It is darker than standard indigo. This somber yet rich color represents deep intuition, professional depth, and nocturnal mystery. Consequently, Navy Indigo is used in professional uniform accents, sophisticated evening decor, and deep-dye denim, offering a more nuanced alternative to plain navy.

  • HEX #00009C
  • RGB 0, 0, 156
  • CMYK 100, 100, 0, 39

Denim Blue (alt)

Denim Blue is a classic medium-blue directly referencing the standard dye used for blue jeans. It is a workwear and casual staple. This dependable color symbolizes durability, reliability, and casual Americana. Thus, Denim Blue is foundational in jeans manufacturing, casual fashion branding, and rustic interior design, representing rugged comfort and timeless, everyday style.

  • HEX #1560BD
  • RGB 21, 96, 189
  • CMYK 89, 49, 0, 26

Majorelle Blue

Majorelle Blue is a vivid, electrifying ultramarine created by French painter Jacques Majorelle for his Marrakech garden. It is an intensely saturated, almost artificial-looking blue. This striking shade represents artistic boldness, exotic oasis, and vibrant energy. Consequently, Majorelle Blue is iconic in the Jardin Majorelle, fashion design, and Moroccan-inspired decor, creating a stunning, unforgettable visual impact.

  • HEX #6050DC
  • RGB 96, 80, 220
  • CMYK 56, 64, 0, 14

Light Ice Blue

Light Ice Blue is an extremely pale, whitish blue with a stronger cyan presence than similar ice colors. It resembles thin, sun-hit ice. This crisp, cool shade evokes fragile cold, breathable air, and hygienic purity. Therefore, Light Ice Blue is ideal for product packaging for water or breath mints, winter wedding themes, and medical facility accents, suggesting absolute freshness and cleanliness.

  • HEX #E2FDFF
  • RGB 226, 253, 255
  • CMYK 11, 1, 0, 0

Sky Pastel

Sky Pastel is a soft, light azure with a dreamy, diluted quality, like the sky on a hazy summer afternoon. It is a gentle and approachable pastel. This soothing color represents daydreams, soft focus, and gentle optimism. Accordingly, Sky Pastel is frequently used in children’s book illustrations, relaxed loungewear, and soothing social media graphics, fostering a sense of calm, hopeful relaxation.

  • HEX #A0DDFF
  • RGB 160, 221, 255
  • CMYK 37, 13, 0, 0

Cool Blue

Cool Blue is a bright, medium periwinkle-blue with a clear, crisp undertone. It is a digitally friendly, modern shade. This vibrant hue signifies clarity, calm confidence, and sleek modernity. Hence, Cool Blue is effective for tech startup branding, app icons, and contemporary office design, communicating a sense of efficient, clean, and forward-thinking energy.

  • HEX #7189FF
  • RGB 113, 137, 255
  • CMYK 56, 46, 0, 0

Digital Blue

Digital Blue is a medium-light, saturated blue that mimics the standard blue used in digital interfaces and default hyperlinks. It is a color of the information age. This functional shade represents connectivity, trustworthiness, and clickable interaction. Thus, Digital Blue is ubiquitous in user interface design, cybersecurity logos, and online learning platforms, serving as a reliable and expected visual cue for action.

  • HEX #5465FF
  • RGB 84, 101, 255
  • CMYK 67, 60, 0, 0

Soft Serum Blue

Soft Serum Blue is a muted, grayish medium blue with a smooth, liquid-suggestive quality. The name implies a scientific or cosmetic fluid. This subdued shade evokes clinical efficacy, smooth application, and subtle reliability. Consequently, Soft Serum Blue is commonly found in skincare and cosmetic packaging, lab equipment design, and professional software interfaces, suggesting advanced, gentle, and effective solutions.

  • HEX #758ECD
  • RGB 117, 142, 205
  • CMYK 43, 31, 0, 20

Bright Royal Blue

Bright Royal Blue is a deep, vivid blue that is lighter and more vibrant than traditional royal blue. It maintains a regal feel with added energy. This luminous shade symbolizes dynamic leadership, celebratory excellence, and modern nobility. Therefore, Bright Royal Blue is used for championship sports ribbons, premium event branding, and vibrant formal wear, denoting high achievement with a contemporary flair.

  • HEX #318CE7
  • RGB 49, 140, 231
  • CMYK 79, 39, 0, 9

Deep Twilight Blue

Deep Twilight Blue is a very dark, desaturated indigo that captures the sky in the moments after sunset. It is a color of transition and depth. This mysterious hue represents contemplation, profound calm, and the threshold of night. Accordingly, Deep Twilight Blue is powerful in astronomy applications, luxury bedding, and spiritual meditation aids, creating an atmosphere of deep, peaceful introspection.

  • HEX #283593
  • RGB 40, 53, 147
  • CMYK 73, 64, 0, 42

Ocean Blue

Ocean Blue is a clear, strong azure that reflects the surface of tropical seas on a sunny day. It is a naturally vibrant and inviting color. This refreshing shade signifies adventure, refreshment, and expansive life. Consequently, Ocean Blue is a staple in cruise line marketing, water sports equipment, and summer collection fashion, evoking the call of the open, adventurous sea.

  • HEX #1E88E5
  • RGB 30, 136, 229
  • CMYK 87, 41, 0, 10

True Teal Blue

True Teal Blue is a balanced, medium blue-green, a definitive version of teal. It equally blends the calm of blue and the renewal of green. This sophisticated color represents emotional equilibrium, refined taste, and communicative clarity. Thus, True Teal Blue is a preferred choice for corporate design in creative industries, upscale home decor, and jewelry, offering a distinctive and polished alternative to standard blues.

  • HEX #008B8B
  • RGB 0, 139, 139
  • CMYK 100, 0, 0, 45

title: Shades of Green: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Green is more than a simple color. It reflects growth, balance, and renewal, shaping how we feel and how spaces come alive. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of green, from soft mint to deep forest tones, each with its own character and story. Every shade includes hex, RGB, and CMYK codes … Read more
content:
Green is more than a simple color. It reflects growth, balance, and renewal, shaping how we feel and how spaces come alive. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of green, from soft mint to deep forest tones, each with its own character and story.

Every shade includes hex, RGB, and CMYK codes for easy use across digital and print projects. You will also learn the meaning and common uses behind each green, helping you choose with clarity and purpose.

By the end of this guide, you will understand how each green looks, feels, and functions. Picking the right shade for design, art, branding, or decor becomes simple and intuitive.

Let’s step into the rich and refreshing world of green shades.

Apple Green

Apple Green is a crisp, vibrant yellow-green reminiscent of Granny Smith apples. It gained popularity in the 1950s with the rise of kitchen appliances and has since become a symbol of freshness and vitality. Moreover, this shade bridges the gap between yellow’s energy and green’s calm, making it ideal for eco-friendly branding. Apple Green conveys youthfulness, health, and innovation. Therefore, designers often use it in food packaging, sportswear, and digital interfaces to attract attention without overwhelming the viewer.

  • HEX #8DB600
  • RGB 141, 182, 0
  • CMYK 22, 0, 100, 29

Chartreuse

Chartreuse takes its name from a French liqueur made by Carthusian monks since the 18th century. Originally, the drink’s color varied, but by the early 1900s, it stabilized into this vivid yellow-green. This shade is one of the most luminous in the visible spectrum. Chartreuse represents boldness, originality, and transformation. As a result, it appears frequently in avant-garde fashion, warning signs, and experimental art installations.

  • HEX #CCFF00
  • RGB 204, 255, 0
  • CMYK 20, 0, 100, 0

Lime Green

Lime Green emerged as a distinct color name in the mid-20th century alongside synthetic dyes and fluorescent pigments. Its electric intensity made it a staple of 1980s and 1990s pop culture. Unlike natural greens, Lime Green feels artificial and energetic. It symbolizes urgency, creativity, and nonconformity. Thus, it’s commonly used in highlighters, nightlife branding, and tech startups aiming for a disruptive image.

  • HEX #89F336
  • RGB 137, 243, 54
  • CMYK 44, 0, 78, 5

Pistachio Green

Pistachio Green draws its soft, muted tone from the nut’s pale shell. It became fashionable in interior design during the 2010s as part of the “millennial green” trend. This shade blends warmth and coolness, offering a soothing yet inviting presence. Pistachio Green suggests tranquility, sophistication, and organic simplicity. Consequently, it’s favored in boutique hotels, wellness apps, and sustainable product packaging.

  • HEX #93C572
  • RGB 147, 197, 114
  • CMYK 25, 0, 42, 23

Spring Green

Spring Green captures the fresh burst of new leaves in early spring. First standardized in web color systems in the 1980s, it sits precisely between cyan and green on the RGB spectrum. Its clarity and brightness evoke renewal and optimism. Spring Green communicates hope, growth, and digital clarity. For that reason, it’s widely used in environmental campaigns, user interface elements, and children’s educational materials.

  • HEX #00F0A8
  • RGB 0, 240, 168
  • CMYK 100, 0, 30, 6

Sea Green

Sea Green mimics the deep, serene tones of coastal waters. It was formally recognized in early 20th-century color dictionaries and later adopted by maritime and military uniforms. Myrtle Green is a dark, blue-green named after the myrtle plant, sacred to Venus and a symbol of love and immortality in ancient times. It is a classical, rich, and verdant hue. This deep shade signifies good luck, joyful love, and enduring life. It carries mythological and romantic connotations. Therefore, Myrtle Green appears in floral industry graphics, romantic wedding decor, and academic robes (particularly in Germany).

  • HEX #317873
  • RGB 49, 120, 115
  • CMYK 59, 0, 4, 53

Pickle Dark

Pickle Dark is a deeper, more olive-brown version of Pickle Green, resembling a pickle that has been brining for a long time. It is a murky, savory, and intense variant. This saturated shade suggests strong flavor, preservation, and a more mature tang. It feels heartier and less playful than its lighter counterpart. Thus, Pickle Dark might be used for artisanal food products, rugged workwear accents, or in color palettes needing a deep, unusual olive.

  • HEX #536654
  • RGB 83, 102, 84
  • CMYK 19, 0, 18, 60

Olive Gray

Olive Gray is a desaturated, grayish olive that sits directly on the border between brown-gray and green. It is a utilitarian, military-adjacent, and neutral color. This ambiguous shade represents practicality, blend-ability, and no-frills functionality. It is the epitome of a drab, earthy neutral. Accordingly, Olive Gray is used in industrial design, military vehicles, and contemporary fashion as a sophisticated, non-color neutral with an edge.

  • HEX #6B8E23
  • RGB 107, 142, 35
  • CMYK 25, 0, 75, 44

title: Shades of Red: Names, Codes, Meanings and Uses
excerpt: Red is more than just a color. It carries energy, passion, and meaning. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of red. From bright crimson to deep garnet, each shade tells its own story. We include hex, RGB, and CMYK codes for every color. You will also learn the meaning and use of … Read more
content:
Red is more than just a color. It carries energy, passion, and meaning. In this post, you will explore over 100 shades of red. From bright crimson to deep garnet, each shade tells its own story.

We include hex, RGB, and CMYK codes for every color. You will also learn the meaning and use of each shade. This makes it easy to pick the right red for design, art, or decoration.

By the end of this guide, you will know how each red looks, feels, and works. You can quickly identify the perfect shade for your project.

Let’s dive into the vibrant world of red shades.

Light Salmon Pink

Light Salmon Pink is a gentle, warm pastel derived from the hue of salmon flesh. Historically, it’s a modern, desaturated variant of classic salmon, popular in mid-20th century design for its softness. Interestingly, this color evokes comfort and is often used in nursery decor and spring fashion. It carries meanings of tender warmth and playful innocence. Consequently, Light Salmon Pink is widely used in web design for buttons, cosmetics packaging, and interior accents to create a soothing, inviting atmosphere.

  • HEX: #FF9999
  • RGB: 255, 153, 153
  • CMYK: 0, 40, 40, 0

Pastel Red

Pastel Red is a softened, muted red with significant white added. It emerged from the broader pastel movement in art and fashion, gaining prominence for its less aggressive quality than pure red. A key fact: it’s often called “coral pastel” for its warm, pinkish-orange undertone. This color symbolizes gentle love, subtle energy, and approachable passion. Therefore, Pastel Red is strategically used in children’s products, health-themed marketing, and user interface elements where a friendly, low-alarm cue is needed.

  • HEX: #FF6961
  • RGB: 255, 105, 97
  • CMYK: 0, 59, 62, 0

Melon

Melon is a very pale, pinkish-orange shade directly named after the flesh of a cantaloupe. It became a distinct color name in the late 19th century with the standardization of crayons and paints. Notably, it sits on the border between pink and orange, making it uniquely versatile. This hue represents sweetness, freshness, and summery vibrancy. As a result, Melon is frequently applied in summer fashion lines, refreshing beverage branding, and spa or wellness interiors to promote a sense of clean, fruity vitality.

  • HEX: #FEBAAD
  • RGB: 254, 186, 173
  • CMYK: 0, 27, 32, 0

Tea Rose

Tea Rose is a grayish, dusty pink inspired by the pale cultivar of the rose flower. It was a highly fashionable color in the Victorian era, especially in fabrics and wallpaper. Interestingly, it is one of the first colors to be called “rose” without being vividly red. This color conveys nostalgic romance, quiet femininity, and understated elegance. Thus, Tea Rose is a staple in vintage-themed designs, wedding stationery, and luxurious lingerie, often paired with deeper tones for a classic, sophisticated feel.

  • HEX: #F4C2C2
  • RGB: 244, 194, 194
  • CMYK: 0, 20, 20, 4

Spanish Pink

Spanish Pink is a light, warm pink with a subtle peachy influence. Its name suggests a cultural association with traditional Spanish aesthetics, though it’s a modern color term. A fascinating detail: it has an almost imperceptible coolness compared to pure light pink, giving it sophisticated depth. This shade signifies warm hospitality, soft passion, and Mediterranean warmth. Consequently, Spanish Pink is utilized in hospitality design, cosmetic blushes, and textile patterns to inject a sun-kissed, welcoming glow.

  • HEX: #F7BFBE
  • RGB: 247, 191, 190
  • CMYK: 0, 23, 23, 3

Vivid Tangerine

Vivid Tangerine is a bright, saturated blend of orange and pink, named after the tangerine fruit. It became iconic in the 1960s and 70s for its bold, psychedelic energy. Importantly, it’s significantly brighter and warmer than a standard peach. This color radiates enthusiasm, creativity, and youthful exuberance. Therefore, Vivid Tangerine is powerful in sports apparel, attention-grabbing advertisements, and contemporary art to convey unapologetic fun and dynamic motion.

  • HEX: #FF9980
  • RGB: 255, 153, 128
  • CMYK: 0, 40, 50, 0

Salmon

Salmon is a medium pink-orange hue directly mimicking the color of wild salmon flesh. It has been used as a color term since the late 18th century. A key fact: the web color “Salmon” is notably lighter and pinker than the actual flesh of most salmon species. This classic color represents health, nourishment, and natural vitality. As such, Salmon is pervasive in food industry logos, activewear, and website backgrounds where a friendly, appetizing, and energetic impression is desired.

  • HEX: #FA8072
  • RGB: 250, 128, 114
  • CMYK: 0, 49, 54, 2

Coral Pink

Coral Pink is a brighter, more pink-dominated variant of coral. It draws its name from marine coral skeletons, becoming popular in the 1950s “Florida” aesthetic. Interestingly, it is often confused with salmon but is distinctly more pink and less orange. This hue evokes tropical warmth, playful charm, and sociable energy. Thus, Coral Pink is a favorite in resort wear, retro diner decor, and beauty product packaging to signal a cheerful, lively, and slightly nostalgic vibe.

  • HEX: #F88379
  • RGB: 248, 131, 121
  • CMYK: 0, 47, 51, 3

Rosewater

Rosewater is an extremely pale, washed-out pink with a hint of peach, named after the fragrant byproduct of rose distillation. It surged in popularity as a “millennial pink” adjacent trend in the 2010s. Notably, it is a key color in the Pantone Color of the Year “Serenity” palette from 2016. This color embodies tranquility, modern wellness, and gentle self-care. Consequently, Rosewater is extensively used in skincare branding, minimalist interior design, and tech device finishes to promote a calm, clean, and modern aesthetic.

  • HEX: #FFD6D1
  • RGB: 255, 214, 209
  • CMYK: 0, 16, 18, 0

Dusty Rose

Dusty Rose is a grayish, medium-toned pink that looks like rose pink mixed with ash. It was a defining color of the 1980s, especially in fashion and wedding themes. A fascinating detail: its “dustiness” comes from a significant addition of gray, which mutes its intensity. This shade communicates mature romance, understated grace, and vintage charm. Therefore, Dusty Rose is ideal for bridesmaid dresses, shabby chic decor, and mature branding where a soft, sophisticated, and non-flashy personality is key.

  • HEX: #DCA1A1
  • RGB: 220, 161, 161
  • CMYK: 0, 27, 27, 14

Begonia

Begonia is a vibrant, saturated pink-red named after the flowering plant. It emerged as a distinct color in horticultural and design circles. Interestingly, it sits between coral and strawberry, possessing a unique fruity vibrancy. This color symbolizes lively energy, social engagement, and friendly warmth. Consequently, Begonia is effective in summer marketing campaigns, event graphics, and contemporary fashion to project a bold yet approachable personality.

  • HEX: #FA7268
  • RGB: 250, 114, 104
  • CMYK: 0, 54, 58, 2

Sunset Orange

Sunset Orange captures the intense, warm glow of the sun at dusk. It’s a natural phenomenon color used for centuries in art. A key fact: it’s redder than a pure orange, embodying the day’s final fiery moments. This hue evokes dramatic beauty, wistful transition, and warm closure. Thus, Sunset Orange is powerful in travel and tourism branding, event posters, and sunset-themed artwork to inspire emotion and awe.

  • HEX: #FA5F55
  • RGB: 250, 95, 85
  • CMYK: 0, 62, 66, 2

Terra Cotta

Terra Cotta is an earthy, brownish-orange directly named after “baked earth” clay used for pottery for millennia. Historically, it’s one of the oldest man-made colors, seen in ancient artifacts worldwide. Notably, its tone varies with the iron content of the local clay. This color represents craftsmanship, natural warmth, and organic stability. Therefore, Terra Cotta is foundational in bohemian and rustic design, artisanal product packaging, and warm-neutral interior schemes.

  • HEX: #E3735E
  • RGB: 227, 115, 94
  • CMYK: 0, 49, 59, 11

Persimmon

Persimmon is a pure, vivid orange-red named after the ripe fruit. It became a standard color name with the spread of the fruit in the West. Interestingly, it is almost identical to the safety color “International Orange”. This bold color signifies vibrant health, exotic sweetness, and unmistakable visibility. As a result, Persimmon is used for high-visibility safety gear, fruit juice branding, and accent walls to command immediate attention.

  • HEX: #EC5800
  • RGB: 236, 88, 0
  • CMYK: 0, 63, 100, 7

Vermilion

Vermilion is a brilliant red-orange with a historic pigment made from toxic mercuric sulfide. It was prized in ancient China, Rome, and Renaissance Europe for its intensity. Crucially, it was often the color of choice for important manuscripts and art. Vermilion symbolizes luck, prosperity, and immortality in Asian cultures, and power in the West. Thus, it’s used in traditional lacquerware, ceremonial art, and as a classic, vibrant accent in design.

  • HEX: #E34234
  • RGB: 227, 66, 52
  • CMYK: 0, 71, 77, 11

Coral Red

Coral Red is a bright, electric red with a subtle orange influence. It’s a digital-era color, taking its name from sea coral but achieving a more neon-like purity on screens. A fascinating point: it’s a web color with a defined hexadecimal value. This hue communicates urgent energy, digital friendliness, and playful alertness. Consequently, Coral Red is ideal for online call-to-action buttons, game graphics, and modern logo accents where it needs to stand out without seeming aggressive.

  • HEX: #FF4040
  • RGB: 255, 64, 64
  • CMYK: 0, 75, 75, 0

Tomato

Tomato is a warm, medium red explicitly named after the common fruit. It became a standard web color, offering a softer alternative to pure red. Importantly, it’s less orange than coral but brighter than brick red. This color suggests freshness, heartiness, and approachable boldness. Therefore, Tomato is widely used in food industry visuals, kitchen product design, and friendly warning icons to feel energetic yet familiar.

  • HEX: #FF6347
  • RGB: 255, 99, 71
  • CMYK: 0, 61, 72, 0

Poppy

Poppy is a rich, saturated orange-red inspired by the common poppy flower. It gained symbolic weight after World War I, representing remembrance. A key fact: it is slightly darker and richer than pure orange-red. This hue carries meanings of sleep, peace, death, and also vibrant life. As such, Poppy is used in memorial imagery, folk art patterns, and fall fashion to convey deep, warm intensity.

  • HEX: #E35335
  • RGB: 227, 83, 53
  • CMYK: 0, 63, 77, 11

Coquelicot

Coquelicot is the French word for poppy, denoting a pure, fiery red-orange. It was a fashionable import in English during the 18th and 19th centuries. Interestingly, its name is considered exotically stylish in color nomenclature. This color exudes continental flair, artistic boldness, and uncompromising vibrancy. Thus, Coquelicot appears in high-fashion textiles, artistic posters, and luxury branding to signal sophisticated heat.

  • HEX: #FF3800
  • RGB: 255, 56, 0
  • CMYK: 0, 78, 100, 0

Scarlet

Scarlet is a vivid, slightly orange-tinted red with a long history tied to expensive dye. Originally made from kermes insects, it was a color of wealth, power, and the church. Notably, it is often associated with sin and ceremony simultaneously. This powerful color symbolizes passion, courage, and warning. Consequently, Scarlet is used for cardinals’ robes, academic regalia, sports cars, and critical alerts, embodying ultimate visibility and importance.

  • HEX: #FF2400
  • RGB: 255, 36, 0
  • CMYK: 0, 86, 100, 0

Imperial Red

Imperial Red is a vivid, cool-toned red with a slight blue undertone. Its name directly evokes power, royalty, and empire, historically linked to European heraldry and military uniforms. A key fact: it is very close to the red on the flag of the former British Empire. This color represents authority, ambition, and formal dignity. Therefore, Imperial Red is used in government insignia, luxury branding, and formal accessories to convey commanding presence and traditional prestige.

  • HEX: #ED2939
  • RGB: 237, 41, 57
  • CMYK: 0, 83, 76, 7

Amaranth Red

Amaranth Red is a bright, pinkish-red named after the amaranth flower, which symbolizes immortality in Greek mythology. The color rose to prominence in the Art Deco period for its modern vibrancy. Interestingly, it is clearer and pinker than crimson. This hue carries meanings of enduring love, unfading beauty, and vibrant life. Consequently, Amaranth Red is popular in floral patterns, festive decorations, and youth-oriented marketing to express joyful passion.

  • HEX: #F4364C
  • RGB: 244, 54, 76
  • CMYK: 0, 78, 69, 4

Rose Madder

Rose Madder is a rich, transparent red derived from the madder plant root, a natural dye used since antiquity. It was a crucial pigment for Renaissance and Baroque artists for glazing. Importantly, it is cooler and more purple than many reds. This color historically signifies wealth, artistic mastery, and depth. Thus, Rose Madder is employed in fine art reproduction, historical fashion design, and upscale packaging to impart a sense of heritage and luscious depth.

  • HEX: #E32636
  • RGB: 227, 38, 54
  • CMYK: 0, 83, 76, 11

Madder Lake

Madder Lake is a deep, slightly brownish red also from the madder plant, but processed into a more permanent “lake” pigment. It was a staple on artists’ palettes before synthetic reds. A fascinating detail: its brown undertone gives it an earthy, aged quality. This shade evokes antiquity, warmth, and organic richness. As a result, Madder Lake is ideal for restoration work, rustic interiors, and autumn-themed designs to create a comfortable, timeworn atmosphere.

  • HEX: #CC3336
  • RGB: 204, 51, 54
  • CMYK: 0, 75, 74, 20

Alizarin Crimson

Alizarin Crimson is a deep, cool, transparent red and the synthetic 19th-century replacement for rose madder. Its invention was a major breakthrough in chemistry and art. Notably, it is nearly identical to Rose Madder in hue but more lightfast and consistent. This pigment symbolizes modern innovation, dramatic intensity, and cool passion. Therefore, it remains a fundamental paint on every artist’s palette and is used in design for striking, cool-toned accents and shadow effects.

  • HEX: #E32636
  • RGB: 227, 38, 54
  • CMYK: 0, 83, 76, 11

Crimson

Crimson is a strong, bright deep red with a slight blue bias, originally from the kermes insect dye. The name is derived from the Sanskrit for “worm-produced.” It has long been associated with cardinals, nobility, and academia. This color conveys elevated passion, grandeur, and solemnity. Consequently, Crimson is iconic for ivy league universities, ceremonial robes, and luxury velvets, representing a classic, powerful red.

  • HEX: #DC143C
  • RGB: 220, 20, 60
  • CMYK: 0, 91, 73, 14

Cinnabar

Cinnabar is a vivid red-orange named after the mercury sulfide mineral, ground to make the original vermilion pigment. It was highly valued in ancient China and the Americas for ritual use. Interestingly, the mineral is toxic, adding dangerous allure to its history. This color represents transformation, spiritual energy, and bold statement. Thus, Cinnabar is used in Asian-inspired art and decor, statement jewelry, and energetic branding to project unmissable vibrancy.

  • HEX: #E84B3D
  • RGB: 232, 75, 61
  • CMYK: 0, 68, 74, 9

Razzmatazz

Razzmatazz is a bold, pinkish-red invented by Crayola in 1993. The name suggests excitement, flashiness, and showmanship. It was originally called “Hot Magenta” before a contest renamed it. This synthetic color embodies 1990s pop culture, electric energy, and playful boldness. Therefore, Razzmatazz is perfect for kids’ products, party supplies, and digital graphics aiming for a fun, loud, and contemporary feel.

  • HEX: #E3256B
  • RGB: 227, 37, 107
  • CMYK: 0, 84, 53, 11

UA Red

UA Red is the official athletic color of the University of Alabama, a deep, cool crimson. It embodies school spirit, tradition, and competitive pride. The specific shade is trademarked and fiercely protected by the university. This color symbolizes team loyalty, historic legacy, and fierce determination. As a result, beyond collegiate use, it’s applied in sports branding, energetic promotions, and designs needing a communal, passionate red.

  • HEX: #D9004C
  • RGB: 217, 0, 76
  • CMYK: 0, 100, 65, 15

Spanish Red

Spanish Red is a pure, intense red commonly associated with the national colors of Spain. It evokes flamenco, bullfighting, and national fiestas. This shade is warmer and brighter than many European flag reds. It communicates cultural pride, fiery emotion, and celebratory life. Consequently, Spanish Red is used in touristic marketing, cultural event graphics, and passionate branding to instantly convey a Mediterranean zest for life.

  • HEX: #E60026
  • RGB: 230, 0, 38
  • CMYK: 0, 100, 83, 10

Carmine

Carmine is a deep, rich red with a blue undertone, made from the cochineal insect. This pigment was a prized export from the New World, rivaling gold in value for European artists and dyers. Its production was a closely guarded secret for centuries. This color symbolizes luxury, Renaissance artistry, and enduring depth. Therefore, Carmine is used in historical art restoration, high-end cosmetics (like lipstick), and gourmet food coloring to impart a classic, sumptuous richness.

  • HEX: #960018
  • RGB: 150, 0, 24
  • CMYK: 0, 100, 84, 41

Electric Crimson

Electric Crimson is a blazing, neon-like red with a strong pink shift. It’s a modern, synthetic color born from digital design and fluorescent pigments. The name emphasizes its shocking, high-voltage intensity. This hue radiates extreme energy, digital rebellion, and futuristic speed. Consequently, Electric Crimson is a staple in nightclub graphics, cyberpunk aesthetics, and extreme sports branding to scream cutting-edge excitement.

  • HEX: #FF003F
  • RGB: 255, 0, 63
  • CMYK: 0, 100, 75, 0

Fire Engine Red

Fire Engine Red is a vivid, slightly orange-red standardized for maximum visibility. Its association with emergency vehicles makes it instantly recognizable and urgent. Interestingly, some modern fire apparatus use other colors, but this shade remains iconic. This color universally signals danger, urgency, and immediate action. Thus, it’s crucial for safety equipment, stop signs, and critical warning labels, and is also used in retro design for its bold, Americana vibe.

  • HEX: #CE2029
  • RGB: 206, 32, 41
  • CMYK: 0, 84, 80, 19

Candy Apple Red

Candy Apple Red is a high-gloss, saturated red that mimics the shiny coating of a candy apple. It became iconic in 1950s American hot rod culture. This color is all about surface sheen and pop culture nostalgia. It represents retro cool, speed, and indulgent sweetness. As a result, Candy Apple Red is synonymous with custom automotive paint, vintage appliances, and rockabilly fashion, embodying mid-century optimism and flashy style.

  • HEX: #FF0800
  • RGB: 255, 8, 0
  • CMYK: 0, 97, 100, 0

International Orange

International Orange is a deep, reddish-orange defined for global visibility. It was famously used on the Golden Gate Bridge for both visibility and atmospheric blending. It’s also the color of NASA spacesuits. This shade is engineered for safety and recognition in vast spaces. Consequently, it’s used in aerospace, high-stakes engineering, and massive infrastructure where unmissable identification is paramount.

  • HEX: #FF4F00
  • RGB: 255, 79, 0
  • CMYK: 0, 69, 100, 0

Munsell Red

Munsell Red is a precisely defined, vivid red from the Munsell Color System, a foundational scientific framework for describing color. It represents the prototypical “red” hue at maximum chroma in that system. This color is not about emotion but objective color science and standardization.
